149413251.review:
It looks and sounds like a game straight out of the 1980's, while the writing and humor are cribbed from decades of pop culture and modern memes.
---

Game play simultaneously reminds me of the ancient [i]Adventure[/i] (circa 1980) from Atari, released for the Atari 2600 console smashed into the bones of [i]Rogue Legacy[/i] (2013), while the humor would be right at home in [i]Muchkin[/i], the card game from 2001.

Effectively it's a 2d rogue-lite sidescroller/platformer where you keep repeating the same adventure until you finally figure out the solution. Along the way you'll find 100 different endings, each usually taking a few minutes to complete and then you "restart" and try again.

It's fun, and funny but also highly repetitive. Humor is also subjective and in a game so full-of-it, in more ways than one; your mileage may vary on what you find enjoyable and which parts you just shrug off and try again.

The difficulty ranges from easy to hard sometimes randomly, but it's the kind of game where you are expected to learn from your mistakes and each new attempt should be relatively easier as you go.

Not much else to say here; it's pretty straight forward and you either enjoy retro 2d adventure games or you should probably skip this.
---

Bottom line: this probably would have been game of the year in 1984, this totally would have beaten [i]Knight Lore[/i] at the Golden Joystick Awards, It just showed up a few decades late and got buried under a mountain of modern games.
---

147392506.review:
Desde el momento en que entras en el mundo de "Reventure", quedas cautivado por su estilo de arte encantador y su estética pixelada. Los gráficos vibrantes y coloridos te sumergen en un mundo lleno de personajes peculiares y escenarios detallados. La música y los efectos sonoros complementan perfectamente la experiencia, creando una atmósfera cautivadora que te acompaña en cada paso de tu viaje.

La verdadera magia de "Reventure" radica en su capacidad para desafiar las expectativas del jugador. Cada decisión que tomas, ya sea grande o pequeña, tiene un impacto significativo en el curso del juego. La narrativa no lineal te permite explorar diferentes caminos y desbloquear múltiples finales, cada uno más sorprendente que el anterior. Esto fomenta la rejugabilidad y te invita a descubrir todos los secretos ocultos que el juego tiene para ofrecer.

Los controles son intuitivos y precisos, lo que facilita la inmersión en el mundo de "Reventure". A medida que te enfrentas a desafiantes obstáculos y enemigos, la mecánica de juego se siente equilibrada y gratificante, lo que te motiva a seguir adelante y descubrir más.

145736741.review:
A fun and charming puzzle/adventure game. The game does a good job of giving the player all the tools they need to solve the puzzles, but leaves enough blank so the actual "solving" can be quite satisfying.

The point of the game is to find 100 different endings. It's presented as a standard fantasy adventure story, like Zelda. A young adventurer sets out to save the kingdom and the princess. 

The map is small with only a handful of different areas, npcs, and items. This isn't a downside, it is actually the most incredible aspect of the game. The amount of different interactions and endings that can be found with the few tools made available is very impressive. Some of the endings start to get similar, but it makes sense when so many possible object/npc interactions are possible.

The writing is good. I wasn't ever laughing out loud or blown away, but there's enough cleverness, charm, and humour, that I was excited to see each ending's splash screen.

The combat and platforming aren't the greatest, but this was only really a problem during a short end game boss battle, and another post game precision platforming section. The controls are more than passable in standard play. 

Overall, this fun and clever game worth checking out.

Oh, wow. This is great. Played a little bit on my own account, and then played A LOT together with my son (who also loved the game).

At first my expectations for Reventure were pretty low, thinking it would just be a cheap game with a few jokes. But I was quickly impressed by how much thought was put into the world design. You can try so many different paths and approaches (sometimes with hilarious repercussions) when exploring the game. Just a great experience overall.

It reminds me a little bit of Half-Minute Hero from Atlus - another personal favorite - except this game focuses on spoofing adventure games instead of classic RPG tropes. Definitely worth playing.

145398918.review:
This is more a puzzle game than a metroidvania, but it is genius in design and does what it promises.

Each different ending is an achievement for this game, and some endings unlock shortcuts or easier ways to deal with the world in a manner that you actually feel like you're progressing while you're learning the ins and outs of this place. The humour is good in my opinion (even if that means nothing to you) and you should probably not do very long gaming sessions if you want to savour the experience.

Hm, negatives... I really dislike the unlockable colour palettes, never felt the urge to use them instead of the default one. At certain unlocks you gain "cosmetic" options, but until you get the wardrobe in your house you have to stop the session to swap your skin; also saw very little point in renaming the Princess, the Dark Lord renaming is "meh", and a lot of unlocks change your name posthumously so its nice that you eventually get to change your name yourself too. Oh, and I hate a certain jump in the game, it basically requires the stacking of a couple of enemy corpses and hoping that you either have as few items as possible (ie, just the sword to kill them) or that you manage to stack 3 corpses against a wall to reach that jump. Mandatory that you make this jump at least 2 times.

Annoyances aside, at 33% and 66% you unlock a compass and map (in that order) which work with the hint system, so you're not likely ever to be completely stuck in how to get more endings if you're not braindead. I will poke around the game even after I did the 100%, apparently there's a bit of extra content after that, and I can say I enjoyed this game; too bad that replayability is likely 0 since you will know everything about the game once you're done.

145303545.review:
The way Reventure hides the nature of its true mechanics is absolutely genius. What initially seems like a ridiculous-but simple premise quickly gives way to underlying layers of complexity and puzzle solving. Even more impressive is how the game tricks you into engaging with its systems without ever overtly tutorializing or instructing you.

A masterclass in game design that's a steal for the price, assuming you're not bothered by very simple pixel art.

Very mixed feelings about this one.

It is charming, can be fun sometimes and it is very interesting to just explore, looking for secret passages and hidden stuff.

Unfortunatelly the biggest part of the game is not what I just mentioned but instead a painfull process of collecting all 100 endings that is mandatory if you want to fully beat the game. While some endings are very interesting most of them are not. I mean, you get the sword and now you must kill or try to kill every damn NPC in a game cause there is a separate ending for each of them. Later you get a Teddy bear giving you the ability to hug everyone and now you must visit ALL THE SAME NPC againg for an extra set of endings. 

Things get even worse when you finally save the princess cause now you must bring her to almoust every screen and every object in a game to trigger more endings and every time you do it you must save her again and so it goes. And there is no real reward for unlocking those. If you are lucky you get a good joke as an ending but most of the time it won't even be that much funny and interesting.

Game could be much better if devs were focusing on quality instead of quantity. I wish endings were more like puzzles or small challenges but most of them are basically "bring a certain item to a certain place/NPC", that's all it takes. You eventually get a compass and a map, pointing towards new endings and past this time game is hardly anything but a grindfest.

Not a terrible game and can be fun sometimes but does not deserve these owerwhelmingly positive reviews.

144738594.review:
Reventure is a game by Pixelatto. It's an interesting, novel and somewhat humorous take on the puzzle genre. You're an epic hero, on a grand adventure to save "The Princess" from "The Dark Lord", a typical satirical, metanarrative about knightly damsel-in-distress narratives, which is not all too uncommon these days.

Reventure does little to reinvent the wheel in terms of themes, mechanics or video game narrative, and what it does, with it's boasting of 100(+) endings to discover is rather compelling and smirk-worthy... for about 2-3 hours, after which, the game becomes more and more obscure and the road to getting the remaining 50-60 (or so) endings becomes longer and longer, and the tedium sets in more and more as time passes, as you do the exact same things over and over again, sometimes make a mistake after having already played another "run" for five minutes and have to restart the whole thing by exiting to the main menu and getting back in again (or killing yourself in some way).

The game's humor is, as I described, only "smirk-worthy", never did I laugh or even chuckle. Though this, of course, is subjective. The game's main faults are with its tedium. At the beginning you get 25+ endings in about 40-50 minutes, and the sheer volume of them is funny and, again, novel. Novelty, however, is not quality. Adding insult to injury, the game does very annoying self-promo of the developer's promo Kickstarter campaign, and not stating what it's actually doing, before its too late and you've been tricked to driving up engagement with their page. I also find the boastful description of the game on the Steam store page poor taste at best, simply and purposefully egregious at worst.

[h3]I Wish Pixelatto All The Best With Their Future Ventures. Hopefully They'll Make Something That Engages Me More In The Future![/h3]

Gallo Pinto Costarricense

Ingredientes
3 cucharadas de aceite de canola
1/4 cebolla picada
1/2 pimiento verde (o rojo) en cuadraditos
3 tazas de frijoles rojos o negros, cocidos
3 tazas de arroz blanco, cocido
1. pizca de Sal
2 cucharadas de culantro picado

Instrucciones
1. Calienta el aceite en una sartén grande y fríe la cebolla y el pimiento hasta que estén suaves.
2. Agrega los frijoles, bien escurridos, y fríe de tres a cinco minutos. Agrega un poco del caldo de cocción, si ves que están quedando muy secos.
3. Incorpora el arroz y sigue friendo unos tres minutos más agregando un poco más de caldo de frijoles para que el gallo pinto no quede muy seco y finalmente adorna con culantro picado.

¡Pura Vida!

141407688.review:
This was a funny and unique platformer in the "Metroidvania" style. You're tasked to explore this silly fantasy world to find 100 different endings. Each ending sends you back to the beginning to try and find a new ending. I didn't find all the endings myself, but the 70+ endings I did find were very funny and well-written.

The game also has an interesting mechanic where finding new abilities then restricts your jump height, so you really have to think about which items you want to pick up in case they stop you from progressing. This mechanic, combined with great level design, made for some good thought-provoking puzzles. I was really impressed with how everything came together.

This was a great game. I highly recommend it.

141357883.review:
The good:
+ Simple and smooth keyboard control.
+ Soundtrack is fairly good, although there's not enough variant since the game offer 100 endings.

The bad:
- Not enough optional quality of live feature to reduce repetitiveness. For example, it'd be great if there are save or rollback feature (besides certain item which need to obtained manually) so you don't have to re-obtain same gear or walk same path for 20th time. And while there are unlockable shortcut/item to reduce repetitiveness, the unlock condition aren't easy or take some time.
- Few endings and secret ending have very difficult requirements.
- The trailer promise dynamic story. And while it's technically not wrong, the story feels barebone and it doesn't reflect that much of ending you've unlocked and other actions you took.

The ugly:
* Rather than 100 endings (along with some secrets), actually it's 100 ways to die, doing crazy stuff or doing exceptional things. I also have mixed feeling about each endings, some gave me laugh, some surprised me while the rest isn't really interesting.
* While the game is fun at the beginning, it gets boring after some time where i start to use guide/walkthrough after unlocking about 50 endings and stop playing after unlocking 71 endings.
* Average pixel artstyle/visual.

Unless you're being very patient and like repetitiveness to try new stuff or discover secret, i cannot recommend this game. And personally i wish there's additional secret ending [spoiler] where the villain either give up or build far stronger building after i launch Nuclear Warhead to Dark Fortress at least 5 times in a row[/spoiler].

141034309.review:
[h1] Reventure [/h1]
[hr]
[code] It would be greatly appreciated if you would rate this review with a prize, although it is not necessary. If you want to read more reviews like this follow me as a mentor. If you want to discuss the reviews and talk to other people in my Steam group. The links: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43972666/] My Mentor Page [/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/GuacamoleCenterENG] My Group Page [/url] [/code]

Reventure is a game that I enjoy every second of. Reventure is a parody of Zelda, but don't get carried away by this, because although the game pretends to be a parody, it doesn't have the remotest similarity. Reventure has 101 endings which are achieved by dying, yes, dying, what did you expect?

In Reventure your objective is mainly to die in all possible ways, you can die by drowning, by carrying a lot of things, by a rock, by starting a revolution, even by a DRAGON and etc. In the game there are many secrets and you can even run into the developers. To progress in the game you have to die in some ways to unlock new items and routes that will unlock more ways to end your life or get an ending without dying (something very rare). Every time you die you will unlock a related skin, if you die by a rock you will unlock the rock skin and like this there are many such as a princess skin, a cat, an old man, even a link with an anvil head and more.

I had 100% of this game, but they updated it and I forgot to get the last achievement, but I assure you that I will take it back because it is truly worth it, if you want to laugh for a while and die in a thousand different ways, this is your game.

Edit: Doing the review made me want to get the ending 101 and I already did, I have the ending 101 and all the extras done, I really recommend the game, you won't regret it.

140638766.review:
how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

140127971.review:
Let's face it, the indie game world has spent the last ten years chasing after one genre or another, from platformer to metroidvania to Isaaclike permadeath to Monkey Island style nonsensical inventory management adventure. So what would happen if you put all those in a blender and made a game? Well, you'd get Reventure. And much like a Long Island iced tea, it's shockingly good and tastes completely different than the many ingredients it has. Don't spoil it for yourself, don't look up guides, just find it on sale or in a bundle or already sitting in your massive backlog and play it. It's worth it.

P.S. If you have a SNES Switch controller laying around it works great and enhances the retro feel.

140025810.review:
Extremely unfunny on top of being repetitive, but the worst part is the post-game content is designed to screw with you. Honestly, I just left it feeling unfilfilled.

If your sense of humor can be described as "12 year old edgelord on Newgrounds.com circa 2005" then this might be for you. It was not for me. I cannot see reason to put up with how much of a slog the final half of the game was unless I enjoyed the humor but it just got on my nerves after a while.

Edit: Elaborating on what I mean about "The final half of the game is a slog." SO MANY of the last several endings require the princess, and she's all the way on the other side of the map. Yes, you get some limited fast travel options, but getting to her at all is still so annoying that there were times I wanted to just start with her since her escape sequence is long and annoying.

Doing it once was whatever. Doing it 10 times was too much. It really hurts the game's variety after a while when everything you have to do left hinged on doing the exact same long sequence over and over.

139874283.review:
A game about secrets in games.  I enjoyed it a lot more than I thought I would going in- while there's inherently some repetition to it, the game adds convenient shortcuts as you progress.  Take the thought of "I wonder what would happen if I did this..." and expand it out to a full-length game.  Use your knowledge of video game mechanics and see what would happen if the developers really did think of almost everything.

I also want to give special attention to the way the item weight system makes you navigate and memorize the world while you pick things up in a particular order- it's great and I've never heard of anything like it in another game.

137582042.review:
I love the concept of the game and even some of its unique mechanics, but I ultimately didn't go for all the endings (at least for now) as the game does have an issue with being very repetitive. I think going for the goal of saving the princess once is probably a good way to end. It was also very enjoyable to discover more of the world while I hadn't fully explored it at first, and it does feel cool to become an expert of navigating the world as I collected endings.

The mechanic of having items take up a weight is very interesting as you have to think about how you'll navigate in a session to get a particular item combination you need. Sometimes the order you grab these items will be very important too. The issue with this mechanic though is once you know how to get a certain item combination you know you need, the act of getting those same items for a new session is basically the same. 

This issue also applies to general world navigation as you always start at the same point. It's not fun to repeat the same exact actions just to get to a certain point, to do something slightly different just so you can collect a new ending which had a journey with exactly the same steps as another ending.

The game gives some useful shortcuts and conveniences as you collect endings, but one I especially found useful felt like a grind to get to. The ending themselves are funny little paragraphs which is perfectly fine given the number of endings, but some of those useful unlocks could have came in earlier to reduce some of the padding.

Regardless of some of my negative points, this was a unique and memorable experience, and when I was getting to new parts, of the world, finding new items and solving certain problems, the game was really fun. The feeling of being able to kill or do various things to all NPCs and the game actually acknowledging it also felt really neat and freeing.

136827277.review:
I can see why the game has huge positive reviews because it's very funny and interesting how inventory management makes you have to choose different paths depending on how high you're allowed to jump. I played it a few times and laughed some every time. The thing is that even though there are all these different paths, it still tends to get old a little quick to me, and I guess that's why even after I've found the princess a couple of times, I'm ready to call it for now and uninstall. 

The reason being that as far as true 'game' is concerned, I don't see enough of it there besides jumping over things and finding new and/or secret paths. Aside from that, it sorta kinda feels more like running to different endings and decisions in a choose your own adventure. As you play there are new coats of paint you can put on things, but it doesn't change that the game feels like there's little to no challenge aside from navigation.

Even though these are flaws I had a very fun time playing just for the jokes and the 'I wanna try this' factor. As it stands while I write this, in the store it's like seven bucks which is almost fair. But I'm pretty certain I bought this on a sale, which is what I would suggest anyone else do since everything on Steam seems to be on sale 1/2 of the time anyway.

136457976.review:
La premisa de Reventure es MUY simple, pero increíblemente adictiva: tomas el mando de un héroe que tiene que rescatar a la Princesa de las garras del Sr. Oscuro y, mientras lo intentas, te encontrarás con un montón de finales (exactamente 100, con uno adicional para los más completistas) a cada cuál más absurdo que el anterior. 

[h2]Lo bueno[/h2]
[list][*] Humor muy absurdo, pero a su vez efectivo
[*] El loop del gameplay es muy adictivo
[*] Cada final es 'canon' y ha ocurrido en el mundo
[*] Es un juego que pide bastante creatividad: probar a hacer cualquier cosa con cada nuevo objeto que te encuentras y que funcione es gratificante
[*] Millones de zonas ocultas para explorar y descubrir
[*] Pequeños guiños a otros juegos en forma de aspectos para nuestro personaje
[*] Atajos desbloqueables para que no se vuelva altamente repetitivo avanzar en la caza de todos los finales
[*] Totalmente en Español 
[*] Tirado de precio para el entretenimiento que ofrece
[/list]

[h2]Lo malo[/h2]
[list][*] Algunos finales son muy enrevesados de conseguir, lo que puede frustrar un poco al jugador
[*] Hubo momentos en los que había probado tantas cosas que no sabía muy bien cómo continuar o simplemente no tenía el final exacto para desbloquear más finales
[/list]

En definitiva, es un juego simple pero que acierta en muchos elementos que hacen un juego entretenido y que merezca la pena. Además es de estos juegos que cuando crees que has terminado, tienes más cosas que hacer. Y cuando has terminado esas cosas, sorpresa: todavía hay más.

134757576.review:
Reventure is a comedy game that will please casual gamers and completionists alike, as long as they enjoy this game's particular sense of humor.

#1 thing to know about this game is that it's very silly. The gameplay--and the humor--involve finding as many fun ways for things to go wrong as possible. Content warning for pixel blood and injuries played for laughs, and some language and mildly suggestive humor; I'd give it a PG-13. (My 4-year-old loves watching me play Reventure, and I'm not sure how I feel about that, heh...) There are also some jump scares, which can be toned down by choosing the game's Relaxed Mode; blood and other hijinks remain.

The game's aesthetic is all about lighthearted retro charm. Be aware that the actual music differs from that of the trailer; its instrumentation is reminiscent of Sega Genesis games, and its style suits a comic RPG well. The visuals are exactly what you see in the trailer. During the game you can collect different appearances for the player, both by way of endings that cause amusing injuries or character-changing plot points, and by rescuing characters from other games who make cameo appearances in this one.

The object of Reventure is to collect all the endings; there are about 100 of them. And this gets challenging: it takes careful inventory management to achieve some objectives, and lateral thinking to figure out new ways to make things happen. This game's episodic format is fun and satisfying, well worth the game's price tag even if you discover fewer than half the endings.

134742077.review: Great comedy adventure game with some actual real gameplay heft to it. Actually getting all the endings is seriously tricky and requires real skill, but the game is mostly just a good time puzzle game with lots of comedic rewards. If you want a joke game which can actually have some sophistication in it, I recommend it.

134168979.review:
Yet another sideways thumb.

Goes from Enjoyable Open World to Unenjoyable Exhaustive Checklist.

I'd describe this game, in spite of being a real-time puzzle platformer, as a turn-based version of I Wanna Be The Guy, or that crossed with an item-adventure game. In short, there's a world, there are various items to pick up, and you have to use them various places. It sounds fun, and it is (and even funny!) for a couple hours.

The goal of the game is ostensibly to rescue the princess, but there are a lot of false leads and things that look like the right thing that aren't, they all kill you and give you a different bad ending, out of literally 100 endings. I gathered a lot of endings, many by killing or hugging various people. I managed to slay a dragon, slay the Dark Lord, and eventually, after trial and lots and lots of error, rescue the princess and bring her back intact to the throne room.

But the game really wants you to complete all 100 endings. And while there are hints for the endings you're missing, chasing down all 99 ways to die is not my idea of a good time. I found half of them, and at that point I realized I was no longer enjoying the game, and so I stopped. I recommend this game for 3-4 hours and then not for the remainder of the game.

134133989.review: 100% it's price dense world full of possibilities and unlocks

134077620.review:
An action platformer where you explore the 2D world and go ending-hunting (interact with everything to try and get new endings). Platforming is of pretty standard difficulty; the real challenge is puzzles/finding endings (You have to figure out how to get to certain areas with certain items to trigger various endings).

You can only pick up a certain amount of powerups (like flight, hookshot, bomb, sword, etc.) and every time you die you start over with an empty inventory. Each item you pick up makes you heavier (you can't jump as high) so you can't just pick up everything (you lose access to certain areas but there are often workarounds: instead of jumping, you use the hookshot to reach the same area).

Some endings also permanently change the world (which allow you access to new areas and endings or create shortcuts so you can skip some travel). To avoid excess grind you may want to use a guide somewhat early on to do endings that give shortcuts and then later on to find obscure endings.

Example endings:[list]
[*] [spoiler]AFK in the water[/spoiler]
[*] [spoiler]Go to the dragon with various items[/spoiler]
[*] [spoiler]Use the transport cannon while carrying a WMD[/spoiler]
[*] [spoiler]Take the princess from the castle and bring her to certain areas[/spoiler]
[/list]

What not to like about this game?

There are 100+ endings for you to get in this game, and the game is trying to get the endings.

You can rescue the princess, or not... Do whatever you want. Plenty of secrets to find. You can also randomly find hints to endings you haven't unlocked, and there is a hidden room telling you how to get to the mysterious 125%. You technically don't need a guide, but I used it for the last like, 10 endings I couldn't figure out, and the 125%.

Gameplaywise, its a side scrolling metroidvania-ish game. I can't exactly say roguelike, but kinda is. The map is always the same, but you can unlock slight variances in the world with each ending, as well as new character sprites.

Along the way, however, we encounter obstacles that may result in a given ending, and by learning from our mistakes we are getting closer and closer to the goal. I had a great time discovering more and more endings (there are a hundred of them!) and finding all the secrets and easter eggs. 129982946.review:
Insanely fun and a tremendous labor of love. You start on a clearly Zelda-inspired adventure, only to progressively realise how much of the concept is flipped on its head.
Then you start exploring the possibilities and the fun, finding dragons, shotguns, princesses, burgers and atom bombs, combining everything.
Then it almost becomes a puzzle game towards the end, when you're aiming to find the 100 endings (which I recommend you do): do you have to bring the burger to the evil lord, nuke your own house, kiss a boulder? How do you go to hell, would you rather hug or kill the in-game developers, or where would you bring a chicken to bang her...
If I had two nitpicks : the game gives hints, but in all fairness a guide can be helpful for some of the more obtuse endings. And the post-game (up to 125%) is a bit more of the same, but some of it gets more tedious than the main game.
But the 100% completion is absolutely worth it. The ending you get, which I won't spoil, is again tremendously fun and nonsensical.
In a nutshell: PLAY IT.

129859174.review:
Color me impressed. I wasn't expecting much but came out the side very satisfied.

This 2D platformer takes the typical hero formula and asks itself what would happen if the dumb stuff the player sometimes pulls out was what you actually have to do. In similar fashion to meta narratives like The Stanley Parable, this one plays on this concept and lets you freely explore and get as many endings as you can, leading to hours upon hours of gameplay until you take a step back to ponder what you might have missed.

Maybe by the end some of the stuff you'll need to do for full completion might start to get repetitive but what makes up for it is reading the endings' consequences, which made me giggle and laugh a couple of times. The game also does what it can with its 8 bit style and the soundtrack even on a long session I didn't feel the need to turn it off.

In the end, if you're looking for an accessible 2D platformer with decision making, quirky comedy and loads of achievements, give this one a shot. It's ok to use a guide as well, some of the hints may need some further revision.

127341363.review:
[h1]Reventure-Multiples Destinos:[/h1]

[h1]Contexto:[/h1]

Es un videojuego de acción, y plataformas, con un arte de lo más sutil, le queda bastante, incluso tenemos múltiples decisiones según que equipamiento llevar.

[h1]Historia:[/h1]

Su historia inicia como algo simple, un objetivo lineal que se convierte en algo más entrañable, según la curiosidad del jugador, si tienes un mal día o crees que tienes mala suerte, este juego te hará cambiar de opinión aparte de entretenerte.

[h1]Destacado:[/h1]

La variedad de finales, la forma cómica en la que se pueden obtener resulta algo absurdo, en el buen sentido por supuesto, nunca sabes de donde vendrá el golpe, además de disfrutar como todo se desbloquea a tu alrededor, los puzzles, los personajes que además de los que puedes rescatar, el workshop te permite aumentar dichos rescates, la forma en la que todo se conecta entre sí, hasta romper el objeto más pequeño, el mundo de reventure es enorme.   
 
[h1]Puntos negativos:[/h1]

Lo único negativo que tiene a mi parecer es en cuanto a las mecánicas de combate, al tener solo una forma de matar a los enemigos que no resulte en un final, podrías usar algunas de las armas que tienes por el juego y ver que resulta de ello.

[h1]Resumen:[/h1]

Es un videojuego bastante adictivo, me atrevo a decir incluso que cuando estas con ciertos pensamientos innombrables este juego puede ayudar a que se te pase de a pocos, el completarlo al 101% es otro nivel de genialidad, la forma en la que se te va dejando pistas de cómo obtener todos los finales me hizo sentir en una búsqueda del tesoro, este juego es especial porque me lo regalo alguien importante y terminarlo fue muy bonito.

[h1]Mi Puntuación Es De: 9/10:[/h1]

[b]Historia 8/10[/b] 
[b]Dificultad: 4/5[/b] 
[b]Jugabilidad: 8/10[/b] 
[b]Ambientación:10/10[/b] 
[b]Banda sonora: 10/10[/b] 

[h1][u]!!Gracias por tomarse el tiempo de leer, un abrazo!![/u][/h1]

125006214.review:
A lovely game about exploring a 2D world and using combinations of items to trigger events before repeating the process (with a few things unlocking as you do more events).

The world is about the right size given the amount of time you'll spend going through it. Nothing is too spread out, but there is a lot in it densely packed. It's nicely designed in that it is interconnected, but different paths will be available, or inaccessible, depending on which gear you've picked up on the way.

If you think "will doing xyz unlock an ending?", it probably will. Half the puzzle is working out what you can do that you haven't already done yet. The other half is in working out how to do it, which is sometimes easy, but sometimes requires working out how to get from A to B with the right items, and not too many items, as the more you hold the less you can jump. There are usually multiple ways to get between places, but only one or two that make sense if you want specific gear (or lack of!) at the other end, or to be able to make the return trip.

As you explore, you will find hints that give clues about endings you haven't done yet. Some are more vague than others but they are pretty well done (plus some other things that you unlock, which I won't spoil) and mean you shouldn't need a guide in general (except maybe some of the post-game content).

Humour is well done, and riffs on classic video game plots and logic in a fun way. All tongue in cheek and keeps things brief. The fun is in finding out all the endings, which sometimes have a twist to them.

My only criticism would be that you have to do certain things a lot of times, and sometimes aren't sure if it'll be worth it. Not really a problem at the start as you have lots of low-hanging fruit to do, but it can be a bit of a grind toward the end. I still enjoyed it and got did everything, playing basically non-stop in my free time since I got the game.

I definitely recommend this, unless you hate the idea of what I just described, or don't like 2D exploration/puzzle games or hate jokes. It's well worth the money and, more importantly, your time.

123073667.review:
I think the Lemony Narrator describing your epic failures and their respective absurd continuities truly makes this game twice as funny as it already was by default.

The writing is on point and -as aforementioned- comedy gold. The game design is surprisingly clever, and experimentation is almost always rewarding in one way or another. There are little things to uncover at every place in the map with the right item or [spoiler]totally-not-an-item princess[/spoiler], for example, not to mention progression is subtly being added to the map as you get your gruesome adventures ended by all kinds of impending dooms around.

The gameplay loop is rather addicting because of that, you just boot up and go like "Oh, now I'm gonna try THAT with those items". At one point I thought it would be a chore to go all the way back the more I progressed, but the game promptly had anti-frustration mechanics within that includes permanent checkpoint-like shortcuts in key-places in the map [spoiler]like the hole inside the castle that is created when you bomb the place, or the mirror that teleports you directly to the very end once you bring the princess back once[/spoiler].

Yeah, this game is a must play, I'm not even done with everything just yet, and I already want a sequel.

122436842.review:
For me Reventure was more like "meh +".

Behind this game that promises 100 different endings hides a 2D adventure with a slight metroidvania taste when you look at it closely. Indeed, the world and your possibilities evolve as you unlock new endings, and new items and new paths become accessible. Starting the game, I had fun discovering new endings every time I had a new idea in mind. The devs have a good sense of humour and use it openly at every opportunity. The level design is very well thought, so that each of your moves (picking up items, given interactions) opens or closes the available paths, and yet so many different endings/paths can be reached in this world that is, in the end, not that big.

Having hints dropping on a regular basis is really welcome to avoid the unnecessary blind search of remaining endings when closing in to the 100 endings. Although their helpfulness is really heterogeneous...

But I'd say at some point it starts to become a little bit too much. Yet another "endless" corridor that will either troll you or give you a new ending, yet another silly joke, yet another hill where you should have come with less items so you could climb it... The humour and the game design are ok for a few hours but towards the end I got an overdose. Additionally, the platform side of the game is very easy. Any difficulty you may find lies in finding new endings, or the ideas leading to them. So if you have an achievement guide, you won't have any problem reaching the 100%.

Since Steam asks me blue or red, I have to say blue since I kept playing until I completed the game. But if I had to rate the game, that would be a 6.5/10: "good ideas, but overexploited".

122261404.review: I went into Reventure expecting a simple adventure game that I could waste some time with, thinking I would find a new ending no matter what I tried. In truth, it's more like a puzzle-adventure game where you have to really think about how to reach your next goal and truly test the limits of both the game world and your imagination. The early game is particularly fun as you constantly feel like you're making progress with each action you take seeming to lead to another ending, whether morbid or silly, but I personally found many of the later endings to range from extremely tedious to ridiculously obscure, especially with how after each death you're sent all the way back to the start of the game with no checkpoints or alternative spawnpoints. Eventually I found myself stumped enough that I resorted to a walkthrough, which I recommend you use if you're going for 100% completion. Overall though, despite the difficulty I had personally, I still had plenty of fun with Reventure and would recommend it to anyone who's looking for a fun but challenging puzzle game and is willing to keep persevering and trying new things no matter how many times they're sent back to square one.

122002271.review:
It feels like part Zelda, part old school adventure game, part choose your own adventure. The goal is to rescue the princess from the dark lord's castle, but the real goal is find all 100 amusing endings.

You can pick up items that give you new abilities that help you get to new places, but each one you pick up makes you jump less high, so you have to choose wisely.

While each ending can be accomplished in just a few minutes, there's an extensive world to explore, and the challenge is often figuring out how to get to the right place with the right items. I recommend making a map, and keeping notes.

Finding all 100 endings is very doable. There are optional hints and items to help you find them, but it's fun to try to use those as sparingly as possible.

My only major complaint is the post-100% content felt kind of disappointing.

Es un juego excelente en su tipo. 

La idea es simple, juega hasta encontrar todos los finales que los desarrolladores pensaron. Ponte creativo, usa las herramientas que el juego te da como creas que sería divertido usarlas y probablemente estés encontrando un final nuevo. 

Con unas mecánicas muy básicas lo mejor del juego es el humor que maneja. En mi caso cada vez que encontraba un final nuevo deseaba seguir jugando para encontrar el siguiente pues los mensajes de fin de juego que aparecen son muy buenos. Varios me hicieron reír un buen rato.

Lo único "malo" es que, si quieres desbloquear TODOS los finales te va a tomar un rato y tendrás que realizar algunas acciones una y otra vez para llegar a la situación ideal de cada final. 

Lo recomiendo ampliamente en especial si lo juegas de forma casual, sin tratar de llegar a todos los finales, sino disfrutar cada vez que encuentras alguno nuevo, ya sea de casualidad o porque te ayudaron las pistas.

120435756.review:
This game is fantastic, you are the hero in your own adventure and you get to choose how your story ends. Almost everything you do leads to an ending of some sort, kill the shopkeeper, get killed yourself, drown, fall down a hole, get burned by lava or rescue the princess. There are 100 endings and if you didn't have enough of this game by that point there even is post-game content. Some endings are very easy, others can be quite involved but most endings are fun and funny. The game has a good sense of humor often times subverting your expectations and is great to play in short burst but be warned this game can be quite addictive.

The game also features workshop support, if you want to play as an amongus character, mario or maybe even as a pokemon you can do that.

I probably would never have purchased this game on my own, but since it was free, I figured I'd check it out. Even for full price, I think this is a great game. Just don't let yourself get burnt out like I did. I played this over the course of a few days; if you spread your playtime out, I think you'll be fine. It's a fun game, I think a lot of people would enjoy it!

118194128.review:
Well, the reviews aren't lying. This is a pretty sweet game. Why, you ask? Mainly because it feels that almost no matter what you do, the game is prepared for it and gives you a coherent, bespoke response. That's why there are 100 endings.

To give you an example of the ridiculous stuff they predicted: you can stab the princess. You can become the king's hot femboy sensation. You can break the space-time continuum. You can have sex with the princess (this is an European game, no prudes here). You can engage in cannibalism. You can have babies with a rock.

After a while, you will probably start running out of ideas - and in order to beat the game, you need to get all 100 endings. But no worries; there is a helpful hint system, which most of the time will give you an idea of what you're supposed to do, and where.

On top of that, the world is very interesting to explore, and coming up with ways to get past obstacles is very fun. Usually it involves figuring out how to get this particular item to this particular place - not as obvious as it seems. It reminded me a little of "Dizzy", an old game on the NES, or Jet Set Willy on ZX Spectrum. In fact, I'd call this game a "Willylike" - not quite metroidvania, but more than a platformer. Other Willylikes would be VVVVVV or You Have To Win The Game, so if you played those, this should give you an idea of the game flow.

What's fascinating is that the game doesn't look particularly good - the pixels are huge! - and the soundtrack is pretty average. But the game as a whole still manages to be amazing, purely because of the creativity involved and the interesting world. I also noticed that the positioning of the platforms is actually very meticulous; the more you carry the lower you can jump, so it seems like it would be easy to get stuck - but the game is pretty good at preventing that from happening. There is always a way out.

With all that said, I have some complaints. Getting the final 10 or so endings was a bit of a chore, and I had to look things up online 3-4 times in total. A certain mechanic about jumping is never explained, I had to notice it by accident, and knowing it is crucial to beat the game. And finally, I had to write stuff down on a piece of paper - including drawing my own map (there actually is a map in the game, but it's not what you'd expect). But I had fun while doing it - although not everyone might.

For the asked price, this game is an absolute steal - and a very unique little gem to boot. Big recommendation from my side. Enjoy!

117656557.review:
Reventure is a nice pixel-style adventure with a lot of endings as the main mechanic.
Gameplaywise, it’s a basic platformer, with only a simple jump and an action button for your items. The inventory system is also clever, because the more items you have the less you can jump, adding another layer of strategy.
The map is small and a single playthrough is usually short, but this is where the multiple endings come in. The main objective of this game is getting all 100 possible endings, ranging from dying to different stuff, killing NPCs, interacting with certain objects, finding secrets, skill challenges, etc… It’s a lot of endings, and most of them are funny. Also, every ending is tied with a Steam achievement!
Unlocking endings unlocks some skins and makes small changes to the world, some cosmetic, others giving you a small advantage, so you’re always feeling you’re doing progress. After that, there’s a nice amount of post-game content, where you must do various, harder tasks to get extra completion, and getting everything done will give you another bonus ending.
You can see it was made with passion, and there are a lot of jokes and references. There’s even a mechanic where you save NPCs from cages, that will automatically unlock them by subscribing in the Steam Workshop. That’s a clever way to seamlessly integrate it.
An easy recommendation, since I had a lot of fun getting every single ending, even if it gets repetitive at some points.

(обзор на русике в коментах)

[h1]Reventure[/h1] is an awesome short length platformer-metroidvania with an incredible trolling and humor
This is in nutshell, but here is more:

The gameplay, again, is something like a platformer-metroidvania. Let's look at each points. Platformer, (I think it's clear why) because you need to run and jump; Metroidvania because there is a lot of backtracking. You are provided with a bunch of items scattered around the world and 100 endings which of 2/3 are not obvious, about the same persentage are hilarious. In general, the game is ready to make fun of your gaming mindset that is formed from  gaming conventions of other games; it's ready to throw all sorts of surprises and can break the fourth wall.

Music is the best part of the game. Awesome variety of 8bit tracks, each for its own unic location. C'mon, just listen to [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jLEfJNO0Z6I&list=PLWmNvC9Qb1d7unonnZ9aykA1piFPzTQt8&index=7] this [/url], [url=(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bym34G1RVwM&list=PLWmNvC9Qb1d7unonnZ9aykA1piFPzTQt8&index=13] this [/url] and [url=youtube.com/watch?v=ojspBM_m6jw&list=PLWmNvC9Qb1d7unonnZ9aykA1piFPzTQt8&index=12] this [/url].

Visuals are beautiful. Same 8 bits as music, but improved by awesome lightning. Every location has it's own look and unic style, that emphasized with own colour palette.

And the cons:
[list]

[*]Well, at one point, when the endings for which you have to do almost nothing will run out, there will be those for which you really have to bother and spend on an attempt for like 10 minutes. Naturally, it will be extremely disappointing if these 10 minutes of progress will go nowhere because you fell on spikes or like that. Briefly, I'm talking about the fact that there are no saves before endings, from which you could load and continue playing, and not turn getting the next end into a routine. In general, the game can become a routine, every time you go for a sword, then for a shovel, then for a hookclaw... it's unrealistically tiring. Of course, there are shortcuts that open when you do some specific actions, but they are not really save you from repeating same actions.

[/list]
So that's it. There is nothing more to say, I think, so... my advise to you is play this game, c'mon, it's worths its 1.5$
[i]Fun to play, good music. For several evenings, it's 9/10[/i]

thanks for reading

117494335.review: This reminds me a bit of the old Kongregate flash games.  I suppose it's in the puzzle platformer category.  And I suspect several hours in, the puzzles might get hard once you've done all the easy ones.  But as it is, it's kind of tedious.  You have to replay the first few screens over and over and over again looking for new ways to die.  That's basically what the puzzle is, you have to find ending in the game.  Most of them are ways to die, but there are a few others.  There are several different ways you can deal with a dragon, for instance.  I do kind of like it, and the enjoy the humor and slight changes in the world you start noticing as some things you do make permanent changes, but then you find a new ending screen, and it fades away, and fades back on that same start screen and you express a little sigh.

115986469.review:
[b]It's a game where you try to find all 100 + 1 of its "endings" in a large variety of ways.[/b]

Its big positives are the extremely intricate level designs, almost always giving you alternate paths to go somewhere even if it seems like you don't have a certain item or items to reach it. Some endings even unlock shortcuts to reach certain locations ridiculously faster. Also cool is that you get to visually see the results of a lot of the endings in subsequent playthroughs after unlocking them, as if you get to see time itself actually passing after each ending instead of just telling you that it is.

With 100 + 1 "endings", the game also wants you to always "start over" from the starting location. It's not so bad after finding the first dozen or so obvious endings—it's even really fun at first experimenting what you can get—but going for the rest gets extremely tedious as their requirements get more complicated or farther away from where you start the game, and the cheap humor from each one isn't really worth it most of the time; it's even possible to mess up a "playthrough", making you start over completely to try again for whatever ending you're trying to reach.

In addition to the tediousness and mostly cheap humor, there's also the matter of the developers advertising their Kickstarter game to you every so often in-game to the point that they can open up your computer's web browser to advertise it.

115491760.review:
[i]Originally posted on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/quick-reviews-3/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

A parody of action-adventure games where the goal is to discover 100 different endings to a generic “save the princess” quest. It basically becomes a game of seeing just how many crazy things the developer predicted you’d do, with a lot of strange and funny endings. I found it very fun and amusing, though some of the trickier endings like the burger run were a little frustrating. Even that, though, is mitigated by the fact that several endings result in permanent changes to the world that unlock convenient shortcuts, making future runs much easier.

If I had one substantial criticism, it’s the abundance of “death by falling” endings despite there being no actual fall damage mechanic to indicate that’s a thing we should look out for. It made me very surprised when I discovered my first one, and there’s very little indication of which drops the game considers fatal or not. It also might have been better if the whistle was weightless; I rarely found it worth the handicap.

114810325.review:
[b][u]This game was reviewed using Version 1.9.5. Your experience on future versions may vary.[/u][/b]

[h3][b][u]Short Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] A humorous adventure game with a surprising level of depth in its design. Gameplay that starts overly simple quickly paves the way for some excellent puzzles, but does so through a gameplay loop that can feel too repetitive at times. Completionists will find a very rewarding experience for a low price, but players that aren't will more likely find a test in patience.

[h3][b][u]Long Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] [i]Reventure[/i] is a comedic adventure/platformer about a wannabe hero who goes on a quest to rescue a princess from the fortress of a dark lord--or who gets himself killed trying to reach the princess, or does get the princess but gets her killed on the way back, or maybe just ignores the whole "princess" thing entirely and runs off to take on some other random quest and/or wreak havoc across the kingdom for no good reason. The game boasts an adventure with 100 possible endings, tons of puzzles to solve and secrets to uncover, and a world that can change with each new ending you discover. It's an ambitious concept for a game, and for the most part it's handled very well--but it's not a game that I think is a good fit for everyone.

Gameplay for the most part is rather simple, with the goal being to explore and interact with everything you can find in order to achieve those 100 endings I mentioned before. Some endings are quick and simple, mostly there to pad out the ending count--for example, there's almost a dozen that boil down to just "stab these different NPCs with your sword". However, [b]many endings involve some pretty inventive puzzle-solving, and unlocking all of them will require you to learn the game inside and out[/b]. Each ending also comes with a unique end card and (re)opening dialogue joking about how your last run ended and how you inexplicably wound up back at home despite it. It's good for a few laughs, especially when endings can also alter your character model in silly ways, like falling in a pit of spikes and coming back with a bunch of those spikes still stuck in your tiny pixellated body. Much of the game revolves around meta humor and parodying the adventure games of the past, and while the jokes didn't always land for me, it gave the whole game a certain charm that I found endearing. Games that focus mainly on this kind of meta comedy have been hit or miss for me in the past, as they sometimes focus more on making cheap jokes and less on making an actually fun game. I was hesitant going in because of this, but I'm happy to say that I was worried for nothing--[b]a lot of time and care was placed into [i]Reventure's[/i] gameplay/map design, and it shows[/b].

Despite the small size of the world, the team at Pixelatto filled it to the brim with clever secrets such as hidden rooms, easter eggs, and many fun ways to abruptly end your journey. One of the things that stood out to me the most were how many secret paths between maps could be found, and how those became a critical part of late-game progression. One of the main gameplay mechanics is simple inventory management: you can only hold a certain number of items during a run, and most have weight that will reduce your jumping ability with each new item you grab until you practically can't jump anymore. Every path is designed in such a way that you must either stay below a certain inventory size to manage its platforming segments, or have specific items to circumvent them; and picking up any item has the potential to close off one path and open another. This created an element of strategy to later runs, as I had to carefully consider which of these pathways I could use with the combination of items I had so I could meet the requirements for a new ending. Because of this need for strategy, [b]I found myself really appreciating the subtle design decisions throughout each map, and it made the process of full completion feel that much more rewarding.[/b]

[i]Reventure[/i] was fun, but my enjoyment did falter from time to time while playing. [b]My main gripe was the constant backtracking, which can make the core gameplay loop a bit of a drag at times.[/b] Every time you get an ending (new or repeated), you're sent back to your starting home stripped of all the gear you picked up in your last run, meaning you have to recollect any desired gear from its resting spot every single run. Much of the puzzle design revolves around being able to start fresh each time, but it does get tiring retreading old ground after a while, especially if you accidentally trigger an old ending while trying to work on a new one--a mistake you will make many times. Some endings unlock shortcuts that make this backtracking easier, but there's no way of knowing in advance which endings will provide these shortcuts, so you may only unlock some of these long after they would have been the most useful. It wasn't a big enough issue to stop me from finishing the game, but I couldn't fault you if the repetitiveness of the gameplay puts you off of seeing it through to the end.

Getting all 100 endings, as well as completing the post-game content, took me about 10 hours to accomplish. While there are laughs to get out of the writing and artistic/mechanical design elements to appreciate throughout, most of the sense of satisfaction you get from playing comes from the process of unlocking all of the endings. I wouldn't consider myself a die-hard completionist, but I enjoy going for all of a game's achievements or that "100% Complete" save file if I feel that it's reasonably possible to do so. Getting the most out of this game requires that you go in with that kind of mindset, but if that's not your preferred way to play, I don't feel like this is a game that you'll enjoy quite as much. [b][u]Put simply, [i]Reventure[/i] is designed with completionists in mind--you will almost certainly like it if you are one, but may not be able to look past its repetitive nature if you're not.[/u][/b]

113807179.review:
Humour comes in 3, sometimes in 100.

Reventure is a game with lots of dry humour. Sometimes expected, sometimes unexpected. Often just plain awful, but the good kind, like the classic dad-jokes we all know and (sort of) enjoy.

It doesn't offer much gameplay after you've completed the game, however the hours it took you to get there were to me personally quite enjoyable. I laughed at almost every ending, either because completely unexpected, or due to the absolutely hilarious writing of some texts.

For those who enjoy long gaming sessions, this game might become a little tiring, as it was for me. Often I had to take breaks, because it was so repetitive. On the other hand though, that's exactly the charme of this game -- a hero constantly failing over and over again, only to be replaced by another hero.

Reventure taught me to be patient, to accept failures (even if intentional). Once I realized it is best enjoyed in small, short sessions, messing around and exploring the (relatively large) map, and then turning it off again. 112685295.review: Reventure is a cute, clever puzzle game with a large, complex world that challenges you to approach it from every angle you can think of. The game is premised as a choose-your-own-adventure story where you are incentivized to find every possible ending - there is just as much challenge in finding all the possible ways you can lose the game as there is in figuring out how to actually win. The game's puzzle mechanics do a good job making you question what is and isn't possible - items weigh you down as you collect more of them, decreasing your jump height, blocking some areas from access, and eventually crushing you to death if you pick up too many. A large part of the game is figuring out whether there's a way to smuggle certain sets of items to a specific part of the map, which can often be a very interesting puzzle to work out in your head. It feels great when you can find a route that works because it rewards a thorough knowledge of the game world. There are a few mechanics that I felt could have been communicated more clearly - it would have been nice to have a visual component telling you how weighed down your character is, since it's not entirely clear which items increase your weight and which don't, and the fact that you can break leaves with the sword isn't terribly well communicated, but besides a few nitpicks like these, I found the puzzle solving to be very engaging. Overall, I do recommend giving Reventure a try if it sounds like your thing.

110724213.review:
Reventure Steam Review

[h1]My Overall Rating: 6/10[/h1]

[b]Summary:[/b] Cautious recommendation. Reventure doesn’t cost much and offers at least 5 hours of enjoyable gameplay. Beyond that, however, the shortcomings of the game become more and more apparent. It’s not a bad game by any means, but certainly not an ‘overwhelmingly positive’ one either. I would rate Reventure as ‘mostly positive’. 

[h1]Achievements: [/h1]

[table][tr][td]⏲️ Time for 100%[/td]
[td]13 – 15 hrs[/td]
[/tr]
[tr][td]🏋️ Estimated Difficulty[/td]
[td]3/10[/td]
[/tr]
[tr][td]🔍 Missable[/td]
[td]Yes[/td]
[/tr]
[tr][td]🎮 Multiplayer[/td]
[td]None[/td]
[/tr]
[tr][td]🦗 Glitched/Bugged[/td]
[td]None[/td]
[/tr]
[tr][td]🚫 Unobtainable[/td]
[td]None[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[b]Notes:[/b]The achievements are initially very accessible and easy to unlock, but become more and more tedious and complicated as the game progresses. I would highly recommend that you use a guide to avoid any time-consuming and painful trial and error loops. Unless that’s your thing, in which case: more power to you, I guess. 



[h1]💚 What i liked: 💚[/h1]

[list]
[*]Reventure got a charming retro look and feel to it 
[*]Lots of, sometimes even a bit dark, humor and references to pop culture
[*]Tight controls combined with some simple but clever mechanics
[*]Catchy soundtrack which doesn’t get annoying, even after several hours of playtime
[*]Features a hint system which guides you in the right direction without spoiling too much of the different endings
[*]Twitch integration for streamers
[*]Many unlockable skins for your character in-game and a ton more, thanks to the steam workshop
[/list]

[h1]🔻 What i didn’t like:🔻[/h1]

[list]
[*]Not much of an adventure game but instead more of a puzzle platformer and collect-a-thon
[*]Almost no enemy variety at all
[*]Platforming sections are, for the most part, pretty basic and easy
[*]Quality of life features are either missing or too basic, which leads to the game becoming more and more tedious as you progress
[*]Extremely shallow ‘combat system’, if you even want to call it that
[*]Difficulty varies somewhat, which can lead to frustrating moments towards the end of Reventure
[/list]

[h1]In-Depth Review:[/h1]
All things considered Reventure is a decent game in my book. Not a bad one, but not a great one either. As i wrote previously, i would rate the game as ‘mostly positive’.

First of all, let me clear up some things because the tags and description on the store page are somewhat misleading. Reventure is not an adventure game or even metroidvania. Instead, it’s more of a puzzle game with simple platforming elements. 

Yes, the basic premise of Reventure is indeed that you play as the hero of the story, who has to rescue the princess from the castle of the dark lord, because the king requested your help in the matter. But that’s pretty much as ‘deep’ as the story gets. 

Most of the gameplay resolves around exploring the in-game world, collecting different items and using those on different NPCs or to access different regions of the map. Ultimately most actions trigger an ending of some sort. The game will then play a short cutscene, you’ll respawn in the hero’s house and have to restart, more or less, from scratch. Some endings unlock new skins for your hero, others mildly change the in-game world or even unlock shortcuts. Most endings, however, have very little impact in the great scheme of things.   
There is a grand total of 101 different endings which you can unlock as the game progresses. Overall, this makes the game feel more like a puzzle platformer or collect-a-thon rather than a traditional adventure game.

For the first 5 to 6 hours of gameplay, this isn’t an issue. Initially you will most likely enjoy the retro graphics, the catchy music, the snappy controls and so on. You will play around with different items and unlock various endings. 
The Writing and humor are often on point. Reventure made me laugh out loud several times because of unforeseen twists or goofy endings. The game also breaks with genre conventions and lets you experiment to some extent.
This is the portion of Reventure, that i would rate as ‘Very positive’. I had lots of fun while unlocking the first 30 to 40 endings. 
After that point, however, it all went downhill, the flaws became more and more apparent (and also annoying), the simplicity started to work against the game or at least didn’t do it any favors. 

At some point, you start to realize that there isn’t much depth to the platforming and the combat. 
The ‘combat system’ is especially bland. The only enemies i encountered during my playthrough were little, purple minions and the Dark Lord himself. With the minions, the combat boils down to spamming your sword attack and killing them in the process. Or you can avoid them and simply jump over them, like you would in a Super Mario game. 

The endings become more complicated and lengthy. Which isn’t that bad, because you can kind of rely on the in-game hint system to give you... well, hints that point you in roughly the right direction. But they are also fairly cryptic, so there is still a bit of trial and error involved. 
Keep in mind that you have to restart from the hero’s house every time you die or get an ending. Even if you unlocked it previously and only triggered it again by mistake.
Effectively, this means that you’ll lose 5 to 10 minutes of playtime every time you screw up. The fact that you have to repeat many steps several times for multiple endings, doesn’t help much either. 
You’ll have to collect the same sword, traverse the same mountain, collect the same fricking grappling hook dozens of times. Just because so many endings utilize them in one way or another.

This is, combined with the simple mechanics, a huge drawback of the game. Most of the time, there is zero suspension while you are on your way to unlock the next ending. After a while you know exactly where all the stuff is located, which screen you will traverse and what awaits you on your journey. There aren’t any moments where you think “Oh man, that one enemy is tricky, will i be able to beat him on this run?” or “That one platforming segment is tough, how will i deal with that?”. Most of the time you simply go through the motions, unlock a (more or less) funny ending and simply start the next run.

Also, Reventure has this mechanic where every item that you pick up lowers your jump height. So you really have to learn the layout of the map and which items you need to pick up in which particular order or you might soft lock yourself. Which often times means that you’ll have to reset your run and start again, from the hero’s home.

Most of the NPCs are very bland and unremarkable. You can’t talk to them much, they don’t offer you any quests, you can’t trade with them, the possible interactions are very limited. Overall this makes the world feel strangely static and somewhat lifeless. 

Reventure isn’t very challenging. Unless you go for achievement #101 which ramps up the difficulty big time. 
Suddenly, the game expects you to clear a tricky platforming section. You only get one shot at this per run. So if you mess up, you’ll have to reset your run. In this specific case, this means you’ll have to travel through half of the in-game world for each try, which takes 7 to 10 minutes of your time. 

I would recommend the game, but only to specific types of gamers. Obviously, streamers and youtubers can milk Reventure for a couple of streams and episodes and simply move on.
If you don’t care about completing a game, it might also be worth your time and money. The first 5 hours or so of gameplay are enjoyable and it isn’t like you are forced to continue playing.
On the flip side, i would not recommend this game to any completionists or achievement hunters. Reventure just feels too abrasive and annoying at certain points, at least to me. Your mileage might of course vary.

La vida de un crítico es sencilla en muchos aspectos. Arriesgamos poco y tenemos poder sobre aquellos que ofrecen su trabajo y su servicio a nuestro juicio. Preferimos las críticas negativas, que es divertida de escribir y de leer. Pero la triste verdad que debemos afrontar es que en el gran orden de las cosas, cualquier basura tiene más significado que lo que deja ver nuestra crítica.

Pero hay ocasiones en que el crítico realmente se arriesga, al descubrir y salir en defensa de algo nuevo. El mundo suele ser cruel con los nuevos talentos, las nuevas creaciones. Lo nuevo necesita amigos. Anoche experimenté algo nuevo, una extraordinaria cena de una fuente singular e inesperada. Decir solo que la comida y su creador han desafiado mis prejuicios sobre la buena cocina, subestimaría la realidad. Sacudieron los cimientos de mi mundo.

En el pasado, jamás oculté mi desdén por el famoso lema del Chef Gusteau “Cualquiera puede cocinar”, pero al fin me doy cuenta de lo que quiso decir en realidad: no cualquiera puede convertirse en un gran artista, pero un gran artista puede provenir de cualquier lado. Es difícil imaginar un origen más humilde que el del genio que ahora cocina en el restaurante Gusteau´s, y quién, en opinión de este crítico, es nada menos que el mejor Chef de Francia.

Pronto volveré a Gusteau´s, hambriento.

109505611.review:
Reventure is a satirical 100-Ways-To-[strike]Die[/strike] Win 2d platformer.   I got roughly 68 of the endings in 6.3 hours, and expect it'll take another 6 or more to figure the others out without cheating.  Played using a game controller.  Difficulty is medium.  

- Gameplay is pretty smooth.  You go around collecting items, and each item you collect limits your ability to jump higher but gives you different paths to travel.  On the game controller two buttons jumped and two opened things/swung the sword/did the thing.  

- There are so many callouts to other games in the universe of gaming that it's hilarious in its own right.

- The music is legit.  Get the OST.  It's got the retro gamer vibe.

- At first everything started out a little repetitive.  That was until I realized you don't necessarily have to get the sword, or give a crap about your character, and then it turned into solid, sadistic fun from there on out.  

- Reventure comes in, what, 12 different languages?  

- The map of the game is insanely creative.  There are parts I want to discover that I haven't yet that I really neeeeed to reach but I haven't figured out what combo of items to do it or path to take yet.  

- After playing a copious amount of time, hints become available that help you find endings so you don't have to cheat using a guide, you cheating wannabe cheater, you.  

- There are different pallets to play with later in, but only two didn't nuke my eyes.  

- The game comes with five million sprites for your character to unlock.  Or however many.  it was a lot.  

- Got it on sale for 2 bucks (and the ost for another 1 or 2). Unsure if I would've paid the full 8 bucks for a satire game.

* Epilepsy warning - The game comes in two modes at the start.  Choose the less scary one.  Most of the game (in safer mode) I had no problem.  There was one ending or glitch or something with minor black&white fast/scattered pixelblinkies that I came across, that I didn't have the wherewithal to write where outside of 'this happened'.  



I like that Reventure exists.  It's the sort of game you play when you want something different than the atypical 2d platformers out there, and is especially fruity ripe when you've played many other popular 2d games on steam and understand all the cameos.  The layout is genius-level creative.  It does start out a little repetitive, but if you play without giving a crap to the order of things and just doing whatever to explore (and wreck your game using) the area/items around you'll have a better time.  But that said, I did eventually burn out after a few hours and need to take a break.  Unsure if I'll come back later and make the attempt at all the endings.  Probably?  Maybe?  Will see.

109356547.review:
un gran juego con su humor muy pixelado lo recomiendo a todo el mundo ademas si consiges los 100 eres lo maximo pero bueno no se que mas desir y no me gustan las reseñas tan cortas asique pa ti
Pelamos las patatas, las lavamos para quitar restos de suciedad y muy importante, las secamos.
Cortamos en láminas semifinas, a mí no me gusta que se deshagan sino que al freírlas se tuesten un poco. Las colocamos en un bol grande, donde luego vamos a mezclar con el huevo y añadimos sal al gusto. Removemos bien y reservamos.
Elegimos nuestra sartén más grande y antiadherente. La ponemos al fuego y añadimos un buen aceite de oliva virgen extra. No tengáis miedo en gastaros un poco de dinero en aceite, le va a dar ese punto de sabor que distingue vuestra tortilla de las demás, podéis emplear muchas variedades: arbequina, picual, cornicabra, hojiblanca, royal… el que más os guste, pero de calidad.
Introducimos las patatas cortadas y ya saladas y dejamos que se cocinen durante aproximadamente veinte minutos a fuego bajo. El tema del grosor de las patatas también va a gustos. Hay quien prefiere cortarlas a trozos muy pequeños, en láminas muy finas que casi se rompan al freír y o más bien grandes.
Mientras se están friendo las patatas, en el bol donde luego vamos a echar las patatas batimos los huevos, reservamos. Pelamos la cebolla y cortamos lo más fino posible.
En otra sartén calentamos aceite de oliva y añadimos los trozos de cebolla. Pochamos hasta que tenga un color dorado, que tenga un punto de caramelización pero sin llegar a quemarse. La cebolla se hará antes que las patatas, así que escurrimos y añadimos al bol con el huevo batido.
Preparación final de la tortilla de patatas con cebolla
Os dejo con un truco que le dará a la tortilla un toque diferente y muy rico, es totalmente opcional. Si tenéis en la nevera cebolla caramelizada o la queréis hacer, sustituid la cebolla pochada por la caramelizada. Quedará impresionante.
Quitamos con una espumadera de la sartén, dejando las patatas con el menor resto de aceite posible, bien escurridas. Si no queremos nada de aceite extra podemos emplear un colador grande. Las dejamos escurrir y luego las introducimos al bol con la cebolla y el huevo.
Reposamos la futura tortilla durante 15 minutos para que se junten bien todos los sabores. Pasados esos minutos esta mezcla ya está deliciosa, probad a tostar un poco de pan y añadidle una capita con esta mezcla, increíble.
En la misma sartén en la que hemos frito las patatas y una vez retirado el aceite. Cocinamos la mezcla que tenemos en reposo. A mí me gusta poco hecha, que al partirla con el tenedor salga un poco de huevo líquido. Para este tipo de tortilla sólo necesitamos 4 minutos a fuego medio-alto por cada lado. Depende de lo cuajada que queramos que quede la tortilla.
Para darle la vuelta yo empleo un plato llano grande que tengo para las ensaladas. Pero se puede usar una tapadera de borde liso, incluso ahora he visto que venden tapaderas especiales para dar la vuelta a la tortilla.
Emplead el método más cómodo y que más fácil os sea para que no se os desparrame, con cuidado. No desesperéis si no os sale, en ese caso tendréis una tortilla más cuajada, pero igual de rica.

A gem of a game that turn the grind in on itself. Instead of grinding exp and loot for progress, you grind various endings ranging from the funny to the absurd. The variety of hints that can be randomly found all over the game will definitely help..or not with procuring an ending still not experienced. Getting an ending, accidentally or not, will progress the game by adding various features that make future runs easier, interesting or weird. With 100 (official) endings, there are still a lot to do in the game but this is where you experiment and explore what the game has to hide and offer. While it is possible to gain the hidden 101 ending by randomly doing things in-game, a guide provided by the community of fans will definitely cut the time needed to do so. 

Overall, it is a game worth playing and buying as you can definitely see and experience the creativity and hard work the devs have put into the game. I recommend finishing the game without a guide as the element of surprise and frustration will make the experience a more worthwhile endeavor.

Reventure parece la típica aventura de acción y plataformas, pero si miras de cerca, encuentras que el videojuego creado por la desarrolladora española Pixelatto Games es sorprendentemente divertido y destaca por su inteligente diseño de niveles, su gran libertad de acción, su grandísimo humor absurdo y ácido, y sobre todo, con su enorme cantidad de finales (101 finales!!). 

Es un juego que consigue hilar muy bien la aventura con ese sentido del humor mencionado anteriormente, con una estética pixel art y una banda sonora (obra de Daniel Parejo) que recuerda a los videojuegos "retro" de hace años, y que brilla sobre todo por sus puzles y porque hará que te comas la cabeza pensando en cómo desbloquear los distintos finales (pues aunque los hay muy tontos y sencillos de conseguir, algunos te harán pensar un rato largo). En algunas ocasiones puede hacerse algo repetitivo, pero ésto no llega a ser molesto, y siempre hay algún final que te animará con esa comicidad y que te hará echarte unas risas. Reventure está lleno de posibilidades y se podría decir incluso que morir nunca fue tan divertido.
