106541447.review:
Alright, I have 99 endings so far. I think I'm pretty qualified to write a review at this point. The game is great. The humour is lighthearted and silly, The puzzles are fun. The difficulty of finding all the endings is spread out well between easy,medium and difficult endings. And it doesn't just do some sort of "1-30 easy, 31-60 medium, 61-100 hard" type thing either. So you'll always feel like you're progressing but still have harder ones to chase. 

The gameplay is fairly simple but that's ok since the game is constantly kept fresh with new areas, environment changes and items. I feel the store description might be a bit misleading though. This isn't a roguelite. I've  seen someone say that this is basically finding 100 ways to die. That's not true either. While death does play a large part in many ending epilogues, if you want to call them that, the methods in which you discover endings are quite varied and not just a matter of being killed/killing yourself in different ways (though you'd be surprised by how creative you have to be for some deaths anyways). 

Now, two important things about this game:

1) So, the point of Reventure is to find all 100 endings, as it says on the store page. It takes a certain type of person to do that. One important fact about this game is it has highs and lows. An obvious statement as every game has these, but it is much more apparent [b]and important[/b] here. The speed & ease at which you find endings is going to determine how fast or slow (and consequently, good) the game feels. Initially it'll feel like you're zooming ahead at lightspeed, but that's only because you can't go anywhere without stumbling into an ending. And that feels great. You'll also experience this as you unlock new items and areas. 

By contrast, the game feels notably slower when  you've seen all there is to see. It feels somewhat frustrating when you've done everything there is to possibly do.....except, of course, that's not quite true because you'll still have more to unlock. To be honest though, the frustration factor isn't too bad except when you're nearing the end. That's mainly because you have all item possibilities opened up to you at that point AND there's a very large space in which you could possibly go through to get the endings. 

There's also a degree of repetition as you have travel more to gather items or enter areas and you try new things only to get an ending you already got (or lock yourself out of/in an area). 


2) The thing with Reventure is that the game world doesn't change. Well no, that's not true. It does change, but the change isn't too radical. You won't suddenly unlock a new map. You will, however, unlock new areas over time. Although there is definitely notable change as you progress, much of the game is static (e.g., the area where you find treasure #3 is going to look the same by the end of the game as it did at the start). Because of this, I don't think Reventure is the kind of game you can power through over a weekend. As mentioned in earlier there is a degree of repetition. [b]Reventure is best enjoyed when it is spread out .[/b]  I'd recommend doing it over a few weeks. Two or three hours a week (maybe a bit more, maybe a bit less) is probably ideal.

That's it. This type of game isn't for everyone. If you can accept the puzzle-platformer nature of this game and all that comes with it (as mentioned above, i.e., the latter part of this review), you'll find it is a unique, silly, fun game that's worth your time. 

For those who buy it, I have one tip: Use general puzzle solving techniques to find endings when stumped.  Come back to it later, try looking at things from a different perspective, pay attention for any possible clues visually, textually,etc.

104806655.review:
The premise of the game is quite good (explore a 2D platforming world trying to discover all the different ways you can die) and while I agree with some of the reviews complaining about the daft sense of humour, I personally didn't have a problem with it.

The two major issues I have with the game are
- Each time you "die" you are forced back to the beginning
- Even though the primary goal of the game is to explore through a 2D Metroid-like world there isn't any in-game map to build any sense of where you have already been or to suggest new areas of progression.

Combined, these two factors make the game rapidly devolve into tedium after you have discovered the first handful of "deaths", as each subsequent death requires you to traverse further amount from the starting room, re-treading paths you have already seen, while not gaining much sense of where you should try to go next or where different pathways might be available. After less than 1 hour of playtime it already feels like a chore to continue.

100686028.review:
Highly recommended for fans of 8-but or 16-bit adventure/puzzle platformers.
This is an adventure game that is reminiscent of old handhelds with modern day game design. It even pulls elements from the Atari 2600's Adventure. The game world is small for its type of game, but you are limited on what you can carry, and your items limit your ability to move through the world.  So that makes you have to find multiple paths to get around this small world.  The result is the perfect size when mixed the game mechanics because it makes the world bigger. There is a lot of repetition at first, but a lot of that goes away as you unlock more stuff and shortcuts. The game also has a good sense of humor.
I didn't know I wanted this game until I played it, and I loved it (I got it in a bundle and so I checked it out). I texted my friends to tell them about this game while I was playing it because I couldn't believe how good it was. I like short games (because I can actually finish them). This one only took me about 10 hours to beat, but then I spent extra time unlocking skins. I wish I had something like this for the GameBoy Color or the GameBoy Advance back in the day. If Reventure had existed back then, it would be regarded as one of the must own titles for those systems.

No I can't recommend this. When the prototype for "the more you have, the worse it is" is more fun than the full game, it really feels like they didn't take the theme to heart.
[h2] Maybe recommend if you don't go for completion [/h2]
Perhaps it's fun if you try to aim for like 50% completion instead of 100%, there are so many weird interactions and it's fun to see which "endings" you can find. But when it becomes a checklist and you realize "oh this item can probably interact with this item on the other side of the map", that's when it gets boring. Figuring it out is the fun part, and sure finding the correct path is a "puzzle" in a way. When you have to repeat the same path over and over again however, it's just not fun. Would've really helped if the game had faster movement, or even more teleport thingies.
[h2] Recommended for Streamers [/h2]
In summary, it's really not a bad game, if you ignore some of the more repetitive endings, and you're fine with leaving a game at less than 100%. Also probably good for streamers, as you and the watchers can try to figure out possible endings together.

99009049.review:
+ sometimes funny
+ very good level design with many paths and various ways of getting around using found items

- forces you to repeat fragments of the level, in the same way, constantly - it's basically the entire game
- sure there are many endings - everything gets an ending. You get a weapon and kill the NPC - and ending. Ok, so you repeat your steps of getting a sword, ignore the NPC and... another unique NPC on your path! But now you are wise and you know that you can either ignore or kill the NPC to get another unique ending with funny comment... but then you will have to go through the procedure of getting a sword again! I hated it and I think that the game undermines itself with this restart mechanic. On one side your goal is to get as many endings as you can and on the other it's to explore the world, but one works again the other! And the further you get in the level the more it hurts to try something new.

I might have enjoyed it if there was some easy to use quick-save system or a minor rollback to a pre-death state to minimize the repetitiveness, but as it is I experienced a unique mixture of boredom and frustration.

96124750.review:
[b]Reventure[/b] is an incredibly charming and delightful indie game. It has you running around a vibrant and quirky world looking for various "endings" the player character Tim can experience. That's why it's called Reventure: After getting an ending, you start back at your house and start searching for the next ending. There are 100 endings in total and so many secrets that it would be a serious hassle to list them all here.
The endings that you can get are so varied and often pretty hilarious, and I am amazed by the level and world design of the game. As you explore the world you discover new paths to go, new items to use, which in turn make new endings and paths possible. That and the more items you carry, the lower you jump, meaning there is a certain puzzle element to the game as well! It's incredible how the devs were able to cram so much content in this little world. Also, the world actually changes when you get certain endings!
While you do have to backtrack a bit to get certain endings, the game does an awesome job giving you shortcuts and new paths to cut down the time to find new paths. The music itself is basic, but does capture the vibe of the game very well.
Oh, and if you can't find certain endings, there's a map and a compass that can help you, although the compass doesn't really help at all sometimes, only the hints that you can find scattered across the world.

I do not know what this game could have done better. It's funny, charming, quirky, well-crafted and most importantly: FUN!

Pixelatto, you have made an incredible first game and I can't wait to hear more from you guys!

10/10

95359372.review:
First and foremost, I'd like to state that I'm only giving a negative review because there isn't a neutral option. The humor is chuckle worthy, no doubt, but the way the game presents itself in this aspect is kinda exaggerated. There are jump scares, unexpected endings that made me laugh, but some of it was just internet lolz jokes we've heard 1,000 times.

The 100 endings are mainly finding ways to die or approaching a discovered ending with a different item or strategy. After a few hours the game became stale and I lost all interest in progressing. It started off strong, but just became tiresome and mundane. Unlocking skins and being able to change your name isn't enough to save the situation, and the puzzle aspects of item usage come down to simple trial and error which isn't very satisfying for my preferred style of game play.

Despite how much I'm ripping this game apart, I'm sure there are plenty of people who would love exactly what this game sets out to be. That being said, I don't plan on putting another minute into this title ever again.

At the default price tag, It's a hard pass... But on sale at $2.99 I don't regret the few dollars that I spent.

95218227.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

94925547.review:
A neat concept with very good controls, though it feels like a game jam game that was expanded into a full title without much thought as to how to keep it fun long term. 

After about an hour in you're going to be doing the same exact path multiple times with, often, the same items. The only difference being where you stop. I'm not kidding when I say that for over an hour of my playtime I was running to the castle and getting the princess, which is roughly 6 minutes, and dropping her off in different locations, maybe a minute or 2, for different endings. 
Some endings reward you with shortcuts or are just genuinely funny, but most of what you'll get is character skins which aren't super useful when your skin is just going to get changed during the next ending you get.

I mean ultimately, it's a fun game and I genuinely like most of it, but it's a game that is just so draining to try and complete that I can't recommend it as a game to sit down and try and power through. Though, as a game that you play in short bursts, maybe one or two endings when you're just looking for something quick, it's great for that.

This game is a metroidvania where you can get to the final area without getting any upgrades if you know what route you can take. 

Every type of death is an ending (Although many other endings aren't derived from bloodshed), but there never is an actual ending

You can collect many different items to help you traverse the world, but carrying too much will kill you (and give you an ending)

You can spend hours running around the world without getting bored, even though you can reach any area in < 5 minutes if you know the world well enough

You can kill your allies and hug your enemies, or vice versa

This game is the funniest thing I've ever seen (I'm not putting a second part to this point, this genuinely had me laughing)

Your hero can possibly save the princess and valiantly return her to the king, or have their adventure end by tripping on a rock.

 11 out of 10, would drop down a chimney to give everyone a copy of this game so they can also rate this game an 11 out of 10

91672783.review:
It's a pretty fun and silly game offering unique challenges. The idea is to explore the world and discover the 100 different endings available. Obviously, the world starts to get pretty repetitive after going through the same places over and over. Also, I feel many of the endings could have been removed to improve the quality of the game. As a vague example (to prevent spoilers), you could spend 15 minutes working your way to a specific room just to find there are 3 different ways to kill yourself in the room, all of which seem pretty inconsequential. In order to complete all the endings, you must spend 45 minutes doing the same things over and over to get to this point. It feels like the devs struggled to get to the 100 endings and many of them (30-50) feel .. unsatisfying. Like they were tacked on. I would have preferred far fewer endings instead of more in order to add length to the game.

That being said, the game is fun for a couple hours and if you don't worry about getting every single ending.

Bizcochuelo básico casero
Ingredientes
 8 raciones
400 gr harina leudante
3 huevos
1 taza leche
1/2 taza aceite
Esencia de vainilla
1 taza azúcar
Precalentar el horno al MÍNIMO. Enmantecar/aceitar y enharinar un molde. Reservar.
Batir los huevos, agregar la leche (seguir batiendo), el aceite (batimos), la esencia de vainilla y el azúcar. Volver a batir.
Tamizar la harina (de a poco) y batir hasta integrar todos los ingredientes y la mezcla quede aireada (con burbujitas).
Pasamos la mezcla al molde y le damos ligeros golpecitos (sobre una superficie firme) para emparejar. Llevamos al horno por 1 hora o hasta que, pinchando con un cuchillo, este salga seco. OJO: NO ABRIR EL HORNO por lo menos hasta que hayan pasado 50 minutos, si no corremos el riesgo de que el bizcochuelo salga irregular. Dejar enfriar, desmoldar y espolvorear con azúcar impalpable o decorar a gusto y piacere ^^ Disfruten!

It's fun trying to puzzle out all the 100 ways to trigger something. I bought this for less than $2 and that's an insane value for how much enjoyment their game gave me. It's refreshingly good unless you absolutely do not like this sort of thing. I'm always walking left at the start, glitch-clipping walls if possible, climbing where I shouldn't, main quest? what's a manequost?

And this game is all about a sense of humor and playing on all these old vidjagaem tropes. And having to comb over something a new way to unlock something else is very reminiscent of a LOT of the older classics for NES. This really did feel like playing a well made classic that had a sense of humor about itself. Like Gex but good and 8-bit. You've seen 8-bit 4th walling and snark but, idk, this just feels right to me. And >$5? get it. get. it. If you can't handle replaying the same map 100 different ways? Why are you even reading this?

91480634.review:
It's a comedic platformer with rather amusing writing and some really weird stuff going on that rewards exploration, and messing with the game environment and NPCs well. Despite what it has going for it, it has some major issues such as the amount of backtracking / repetition required to get most of the endings ([i]granted certain endings do unlock shortcuts or other environmental changes to help reduce, but not completely alleviate that[/i]), [spoiler]as a cat lover, I was extremely upset to learn you have to murder the cats ([i]permanently[/i]) and hear them scream for Ending 101 - this upset me to the point I just dropped the game entirely since I refuse to do it and can no longer get 150% ([i]devs, if you read this, can you allow players to hug all the cats instead? Something that won't get rid of them? - Also you'll probably have to center one that I can't seem to hug for that to work.[/i])[/spoiler], and also the fact that despite the game encouraging you to do crazy things it oddly enough fails to reward [spoiler]jailbreaking the shotgun ([i]by killing the shopkeeper, NOT taking it to avoid triggering the security bridges, getting the hookclaw (you need to do this AFTER killing the shopkeeper as the ceiling prevents killing them while you have it) and the chicken to take it everywhere, THEN returning for it[/i] and killing anyone / everyone besides the Mimick you're meant to kill with it. In fact, using the shotgun on any NPC you're not intended to, including the Dark Lord, causes nothing special to happen at all, not even an ending. They just die unceremoniously.[/spoiler]

Given the fact that the only differences between this and the much cheaper mobile version are lackluster Twitch integration  and community made outfits, I'd say either wait for it to go on sale or buy the mobile version instead as I can't justify the full price of admission as-is.

91314859.review:
Reventure surprised me. 

As someone who is very critical of throwback platformers and isn't big on forced metahumor, this game managed to subvert what negetive expectations I had.

Instead, it managed to combine the world-weary tongue-in-cheek dark humor and copious pixelated blood of the flash game days with a genuine sense of exploration, discovery, and wonder that kept me going and entertained until I found myself completing it 100% (150%?)

To summarize: if you enjoy exploration, don't mind a few crass jokes, or just want to poke stuff to see what it does, Reventure is for you.

91269968.review:
Reventure is an insanely short game (a run could span anywhere from a few seconds to 10 minutes), but the value comes from just how fun almost all 100 endings can be. The writing is honestly so charming or funny that despite the fact I was basically playing the same game 100+ times, I didn't get bored until I had achieved ending #100.

Unfortunately, this means if you don't have the patience to play the same game over and over, doing slightly different (and somewhat tedious at times) tasks each time, you won't be enjoying the game very much.

This makes Reventure kinda weird because it's nearly PERFECT at what it tries to do, but what it tries to do just really ain't gonna cut it for a lot of people.

If you have patience and like "the funny", buy Reventure now, it's like $5 and I will step on your toes if you don't buy it.

Okay this is epic.

[spoiler]Nuked the shopkeeper while playing as a hobo. Social justice, that.[/spoiler]

UPD. now that I've finished the 100% run, have a proper review: this little game is fantastic. The included prototype version is just so precious. I take part in game jams myself, so I understand the monumental amount of work it took to go from that concept version to the full Steam release.

The shtick with different endings no matter what you do is just great, I'd love to see the sequel with even more unhinged stuff, all while tying the endings into a coherent story. Kind of like Evoland 2 did to Evoland.

The graphics style is really exaggerated, I love it. The music, on the other hand, is kind of meh (I still got the soundtrack, but more as a symbolic gesture.)

TL;DR Reventure is good, and you should play it.

91144465.review:
Thinking about getting this game?
Not sure if its for you?
Well lets get straight into this
Controls:
The controls in this game are... Really good, You have left and right movement, a jump, and an action.
While being extremely simple, It feels great to control & use anything you find, Items usually "adapt" to your environment, so your action button will always use the correct thing for the situation!
You can also change your controls to other layouts to suit how you want to play (Such as A/D, space, and E for your action)
Overall very good controls that anyone can get used to in minutes!
---
Graphics:
While at some times can be a little overwhelming with the art being in 8x8, The simple yet vibrant style looks great and brings alot to the game's gameplay, comedy, and so on!
Plus some other visual effects to make each area feel exciting
Graphics are great and really fit the game!
---
Now for my favourite part,
Comedy
This game is hilarious, The amount of jokes, funny endings, references, Is incredible
The writing on everything is done amazingly well, even simple things such as the loading screen offer a laugh
Plenty of stuff to find and jokes for you to get
One of the best parts of the game, Well deserving of the comedy tag on the game
---
Gameplay & Accessibility
The world is really exciting to explore, finding new abilities, areas, characters, there's always something around each corner to keep you wanting to explore.
Since the game has **100** Endings, you can expect there's a lot to do, there will backtracking at times to go back to areas but it doesn't really get boring, While on your way back somewhere you wanted to explore more, You could run into somewhere else on accident and find something entirely new to explore! And as you go on, more stuff unlocks for you to bump into, where there may have been nothing before, some random object or creature may pop up there.

Oh yeah, this game has some jumpscares too, thankfully the devs were kind enough to include an option to turn these off & and a few other things such as flashing colours and so on, A very very nice thing to have and im sure alot of people will really appreciate it being a thing you can toggle

For playtime you will probably get 5-8 hours of playtime for 100%ing the game, theres quite alot to do but when you learn where things are, it can start to speed up a little!

The gameplay overall is fantastic, With few few things to complain about and new content and interesting things popping up all the time, You never know what you may find or accidentally bump into, you can really pour HOURS in just, running around and seeing what you can find!
---
A few more smaller things
Music:
Very nice catchy tunes that don't get repetitive
Efficiency:
The game runs very well with lag non-existent runable on nearly any computer!
Pricing:
For $5~ you get great value! A nice game to pickup if you want to try a new game for a low price, Really worthwhile to get this game whenever it goes on sale
Misc:
Also includes twitch integration for streamers!
---

Overall review:
9.2/10
Everything about the game is amazing, from the art, to the music, to the jokes, with little to complain about.
A really fun little game & i'd LOVE to see a sequel someday!
Hopefully this review helped deciding wether you will enjoy the game or not : )
Thanks for reading.

90861301.review: Reventure is a platformer-adventure indie game where a king tasks you with saving his daughter. What makes this game different from Super Mario Bros is that there are 101 possible endings in the game, which are extremely varied, creative and funny. You unlock them by exploring and interacting with the game. Each time you unlock an ending your character changes their appearance according to the ending. The environment changes too, allowing you to unlock new endings, or simply saving time. For example, after getting the sword a few times in the mountain, someone leaves the sword in your house so you don't need to go there for it. The gameplay is solid with zero bugs and loads of secrets, the art and music are enjoyable too (the ost is 10/10). The only complaint I have is that some endings are frustrating to get and you can get tired easily trying to achieve them.

90778535.review:
Tired of playing through the same old generic adventure story? Saving the damsel and bringing about world peace by slaying the evil overlord? Reventure does what it does best, subverting the standard tropes and boiling them down into one-off jokes that evoke a hearty chuckle when you stumble into the obvious endings. Or a tiresome groan as you shoot for the last obscure endings that require specific steps and tools to find.

Before I point out my own gripes with the game, allow me to mention the good bits. The hundred endings are all unique and some of them did make me laugh or were fairly obvious to find. The pixel art style, while simplistic, is pleasing to look at. The many visual design choices like lighting and colour helped a lot in creating an atmosphere for several locations. The controls were fluent and accidental slip-ups or falls were mostly due to other mechanics making it difficult to navigate the terrain or my clumsy hands slipping from the d-pad.

The mechanic where picking up an item lowered your jump height was a nice touch, if not some source of frustration at certain points in the game.

Finally, for a cheap dollar-store game the world is oozing with content. Not just the standard endings, but a prototype game with its own eight endings, an optional climbing challenge to unlock said prototype and other post-content discoveries that were actually fun to get.

Now on to the weaker elements of Reventure.

The “comedy” is hit or miss. Using a mixture of referential humour and surface-level observations to spark a laugh. Some jokes managed to make me chuckle, others left me with barely a smile.

Given that the game has a total of a hundred different endings to find not all of them can be a breeze to get. About a third of the endings require a specific route, which means travelling and collecting the necessary items in a specific order and hoping you don't mess any of it up. Or, as is sometimes the case, stumbling into a different ending by mistake.

Many of the endings also require similar elements, such as facing the dark lord with various items or saving the princess in a variety of ways. And while some of these endings aren't too bad to get to, having to walk the same path just to interact with the same NPC but with slightly different gear made it a bit of a chore.

In the end Reventure isn't anything revolutionary, but a nice time waster if you've got a buck to spare.

90665088.review:
This is a comedy puzzle game based around finding all 100 ways to fail at a short quest. Your natural sense of curiosity and the game's built-in hint features give you a good shot at finishing the game without consulting a guide, but the 101st ending is pretty out-there. The gameplay can get a bit tedious, but it's pretty good about adding quality of life features as you rack up endings. 

The essential part of any comedy game is the humor. Thankfully, Reventure excels at this. It has a dark, tongue-in-cheek sense of humor that exercises moderate restraint with regards to pop-culture references. I laughed a lot while playing this game.



The game has a handful of jumpscares, but you can turn them off completely in the options menu. All of the jumpscares are humorous in nature, but they are loud and screamy.

89275761.review:
Reventure is a Choose Your Own Death game wearing the skin of a Legend of Zelda parody.  The gameplay consists of exploring the map, finding secrets, finding gear that lets you do different things, and then finding the most creative possible way to get yourself killed using said gear.  

With 100 endings to find, there's enough content to keep you going for a while; the writing is witty enough to keep the player engaged and invested in finding the next ridiculous fate they can dish out, and the manner in which your previous character died often influences who you'll be playing as next.  

This is another area where the game sets itself apart; did your hapless adventurer jump under an elevator looking for secrets, only to get crushed flat?  Your next character is technically the same character, except he's now a boneless mass of flesh that flails about through sheer willpower alone.  There are no new abilities or gameplay differences depending on your current look, sadly, which I think is something of a missed opportunity; still, it's worth finding new endings just to see what it does to you next. 

For only $8, Reventure is definitely worth your money; people who are into secret hunting or 100% completion will get the most mileage out of the game, but even if you don't intend to plumb every secret the game has to offer, it's still fun trying to figure out what kind of outrageous bullshit you can pull off next, and whether the game will treat you to it with an ending that shows the developers knew you would try that outrageous bullshit.

Utterly brilliant. I got this game through a bundle somewhere because I bought a bunch of Unreal Engine and Blender ebooks. I'm really glad I picked it up!

It's fun, witty, and charming, a pixelart platform/adventure game that is self-aware. As the name implies, it's meant to be played over and over again. You will meet your demise in any number of ways, and the game just continues the storyline afterwards. Very fun, very replayable. I look forward to more releases from this publisher.

88312326.review:
Reventure is edgy and cynical about video games, yet it comes from a clear place of affection. Nobody draws pixels this sharp and chunky unless they genuinely intend to, it does not happen by accident. I didn't always enjoy the game but it delivered absolutely everything it promises.

So, you wake up. You're a hero. You go get a sword from the local cave. You decide to stab the old man who gives it to you. That's an ending. You get a unique cutscene.

You wake up. You do not grab a sword. You grab a stack of bombs instead. You plant a bomb and sit on it. You die. That's an ending. You get a unique cutscene. You wake up as an ambulatory pile of ash in the shape of a man. New skin unlocked.

That's two out of 100 endings. I'm not spoiling any others. Every item you collect is a verb, to be rubbed against every noun in the game or enable you to get to other verbs you can bash against other nouns.

This is a frighteningly well-laid-out game, every time I thought "Surely THIS is a softlock" I discovered that, no, there was in fact a secret passage out of the jam I was in or a clever way to use items to bypass it. There's a LOT of secrets in this thing and if you want to genuinely complete the game you're going to need to become intimately familiar with them all.

The humor of this game can feel mean-spirited at times. Getting all the endings requires a lot of shameless murder, and a willingness to do absolutely suicidally stupid things for the sake of an achievement and some pithy text. Like old Sierra adventures, half the fun is casting about and inventing new ways to die, or seeing what the latest game over animation is. That's great, I respect that. I didn't always laugh at the joke but I loved the process of getting to each one, mostly.

I say mostly because by the time you're down to the last, call it 25-ish endings you'll probably know exactly how to checkbox each one OR you'll be completely in the dark as to what the game wants from you. Happily, collectable hint scraps are plentiful, and there's a wiki off-site if you really need it.

You can also grab new skins from the Steam workshop or find them dangling in cages around the game world. (Even ones that, uh, are playing a bit loose with copyright. When I wrecked one of these and the Black Mage from Final Fantasy dropped out, I had a very "what?" reaction. Still cool though.)

I feel like this game would probably appeal most to explorers and achievement-hunters. When you're down to that last clump of items on your checklist and you're facing the slog of walking around the map doing things in a particular order AGAIN just to get another stamp on your card, it can be fatiguing.

Still... yeah, on the whole this is pretty great and I'm looking forward to whatever this team does next time.

Delightful combination of Metroidvania and Dumb Ways To Die. It's also got a mechanic that seems really obvious but I'm not sure I've ever seen it before: You can initially jump 3 squares high. Every item you collect reduces your jump height by half a square. Some areas are explorable with jump height 1, some with jump height 2, some require jump height 3. Many require certain items or combinations of items to reach.
And your ultimate goal is to reach each of the 100 endings in the game, some of which are easy, many of which require careful planning, tricky exploration, or both. 

If you have any kind of fondness for exploration platformers with a variety of ways to move around, pick this one up. Recommended.

Some players may get bored from the repetitive nature, but I definitely saw the creativity and work the developers put in and that made me want to see the game through completely.

87341393.review:
Low-rez 2D sidescrolling platformer RPG.  You are an adventurer, setting out on an adventure that has a hundred possible endings.  Rescue the princess.  Slay the dragon.  Climb the mountain.  Catch the chicken.  Strangle the shopkeeper.  Marry the king.  Or something.

There are literally a hundred ways to come to a story ending, all starting with you getting out of bed.  Some endings are happy, some are tragic, and some are simply peculiar, but all (except perhaps one) roll into the next beginning, with the world mostly the same as before, except in those places where you've left your mark.  Explore a little further with each playthrough, discover all the objects that can help you, find all the paths, and don't be afraid to die in a new and entertaining fashion.

Got it in a HB bundle, effectively for $1.00.  The current store price of $7.99 is roughly the same as the price of a fast food meal, and the game will last longer and is probably better for you.

Reventure fue desarrollado por un estudio español, que ahora es una desarrolladora independiente gracias a este título y a la buena acogida que a tenido en Steam, compralo y apoya al estudio, y así podremos ver con que nos sorprenderá Pixelatto en el futuro :D

86698752.review:
This is a mild positive review. I felt I needed to give an unenthusiastic positive review because it’s exactly what this game needs. I really can’t give it a negative review, that would be dishonest.

Reventure has a really good humor. I laughed way more than I usually do when playing a game. It’s filled with cute references and homages to gaming.

The goal of the game is to find all the 100 endings. The length of a run from the start (waking up from bed) to an ending is between a few seconds and a dozen of minutes.

In a way, it’s a puzzle game where you have to figure out what could constitute an ending and how to trigger it. This sounds frustrating, but it’s really not: all endings are very easy to figure out, and the game gives you  hints (albeit sometimes very obscure.) You’ll basically have to think a few seconds before every run and plan how you’ll get to the end, which path to take, which items to take etc. There is no skill involved, the game is better for it, since this would have removed from the great focus of the game (the humor).

This is much closer to a DLC Quest than a Rogue Legacy. Though it’s way longer and more subtle than DLC Quest.

[b] Problems [/b]

tl;dr too much repetition, some confusing puzzles.

The iterative nature of the game has problems though: You’ll end up going through the same 1-2 minutes paths dozen of times. You get shortcuts, but depending on the order you unlocked the endings, it will be way too late and you won’t need them anymore. Plus, the shortcuts are only of relative help, because most of the time you’ll need specific items to get new endings, so you’ll have to go get them before using the shortcuts.

On top of that, there is always one or two puzzles that will baffle and confuse you, even if the puzzles are all easy. Which will be frustrating.

[b] Summary [/b]

I maintain, this is a good game. Although it expectedly deteriorate the more you play it. I’m satisfied and had a fun time playing it. But I won’t 100% it because the late game is more tedious than fun.

85990524.review:
I wasn't sure what to expect going into this game. It was recommended to me to kill time.

I started playing and felt myself getting engrossed in the world, discovering things that surprised me or sometimes just made me cackle. When you first start out, you'll find that just about every interaction you can do triggers an ending. As you progress, this slows down significantly. You learn to balance which items you take and what routes you can take, and it becomes a game of trying things progressively further out of the way, which gets pretty tedious. However, this culminates in a satisfying finale that makes it worth it.

I'll say that some of the endings are particularly finicky about their requirements and one particular ending I would never have found on my own (Ending #47) which made me a little frustrated. For the most part, you can take a tiered approach from trying things out at random, reading the hints, to following the compass if applicable to that particular ending.

Also, you can hug just about everything. Results will vary.

85974326.review:
It is an amazing, obnoxious, and thoroughly hilarious game
I have genuinely laughed out loud at the events you as the "hero" can bring about, the consequences thereof, and at the silliness imparted into the game.
It is a delight to jump into and play for a bit or for an extended period as you travel, explore, and experience all the game offers. There are literally one hundred and one achievements many of which are actually about the many ways in which you can......comple.....finis.....end the game. "Losing" just isn't the right word as it continues on after each attempt, end, etc. one encounters. This is not stated with any negative sense at all, it is a glorious and genuine delight. The developers put a good amount of effort into detailing the many hilarious ways in which you can end the game--seriously, "ending" or "losing" the game just isn't the way to think about the game and what you do as the hero of the story.
For a couple bucks, this game is just wonderful and is easily worth more than one might think.
Please consider getting it and just enjoying an uplifting, truly enjoyable, and laugh-inducing experience.

85862923.review:
I liked this game initially when I got it. It's extremely funny and has surprising amounts of open world, but dies out really quickly.

The world becomes hell. The underground punishes you for packing too much and too little at the same time.
The remaining endings now require incredibly precised steps for the perfect run. 
This descends into a trial and error cycle with the left over endings including items that are scattered all around the map, causing a restart 15 minutes in because you did something in the wrong order.

The game slows down to a halt, you're no longer discovering things from exploring and seeing interesting items while attempting a ending.
All that is left are notes. These can be a breeze to get, or they're just not worth getting. These notes are cryptic and you wont do them anyway.


I accidentally Ctrl + A (highlights all of the writing and I typed a letter so poof, it's all gone) 
while writing an hour of this so it's very bare bones.

84929855.review:
I recommend Reventure to anyone who enjoyed adventure platformer games from back in the day because this pays homage to the retro games before it. I played through over 30 endings before I decided that I had enjoyed enough of the game.
Here's what you need to know:
+Plays well off of what you'd find in Zelda games, with a consistent well done look & sounds.
+100 endings can be found in a wide variety of obvious (death, killing, etc) and non obvious ways.
+Jump height is limited by number of items carried, with a few exceptions, which brings some strategy to what you pick up affecting what areas you can access.
+Items can allow access to certain areas, environmental effects, certain abilities, or certain endings
+The charm and humor of the game are great, often in parody but sometimes in original content.
?The hint system is alright where slips of paper give a phrase about what a specific numbered ending might involve. Some might be too vauge to make sense of.
-Some parts such as picking up certain equipment can get repetitive, though certain equipment becomes easier to get either when completing certain endings or a number of endings.
?There really isnt much in terms of enemies to fight, but this game isnt about defeating a bunch of enemies either.

84495558.review:
[i]El humor es fundamental cuando se quiere hacer un producto totalmente alocado y combinarlo con un juego de “100” finales distintos, puede salir algo muy memorable, veamos de que va Reventure.[/i]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]+Contexto del juego: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Desarrollado y distribuido por Pixelatto, un juego popular en streamers, tiene un gancho atractivo que es los 100 finales distintos, esto atrajo muchas miradas.
[/list]

[h1]+Historia: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Es la típica historia de un héroe que tiene que salvar a la princesa del villano en turno, pero con varios cambios, dependerá de ti cómo será la historia (los finales que obtengas afectarán a la partida).
[/list]

[h1]+Gameplay: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Es un juego de plataformas y puzles, con muchas combinaciones y decisiones, a partir de aquí veremos los 100 finales, todo depende de ti. Ahora les diré algunos ejemplos: si agarras la espada y matas al rey…obtendrás un final, si agarras la espada y matas a un guardia… obtendrás otro final, si obtienes la pala y cavas en un sitio prohibido…obtendrás otro final; entonces de esta forma obtienes muchas opciones, además como ya mencioné, algunas afectarán a tu partida, también puedes desbloquear varios skins.
[*]¿Juego de puzles? Si, yo lo califico así, porque tienes que resolver diferentes encrucijadas para obtener otros finales, siempre tendrás que estar pensando como llegar a cierto punto con cierta arma u objeto.
[*]No existen niveles, todo es un mapa conectado divido en pequeños sectores, algunos escenarios con temas (desierto, playa, bosque, montaña, etc.) Además que hay algunos secretos (ayudantes ocultos, ítems de un solo uso, paleta de colores para crear un efecto en la pantalla, etc.)
[*]Lleno de humor, demasiado humor, referencias a sagas famosas de videojuegos y algunos indies, varios memes y otras referencias de la cultura pop, también suele romper la 4ta pared, es genial y complementa al sentido general del juego. Recomiendo jugarlo en español, porque tiene muchas referencias a los memes de nuestro idioma (CALLESE VIEJO LES***NO).
[*]Cuando saques tu primer final, tendrás a tu disposición la lista de finales que tienes y a veces con algunas pistas, aquí podrás ver los finales que has obtenido, además de cambiar tu skin y el nombre del protagonista. 
[*]También puedes iniciar una partida sin guardar.

[*]Ahora veamos algunos problemas:
-Entender el concepto del juego: no es un problema, pero es necesario entender el juego correctamente: es un juego donde tú haces la historia y te invita a buscar diferentes formas de acabar el juego, es importante entender esto, para evitar confusiones de hacia donde ir o si quieres recurrir a una guía (lo recomiendo si te queda atorado en un punto).
[/list]

[h1]+Gráficos: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Pixelart, es demasiado básico, pero no es lo importante del juego, además que incluye varias paletas ocultas para así tener un cambio estético (Gameboy, monocromatico, matices oscuros, etc.) 
[/list]

[h1]+Música y sonido: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Chiptune, tiene pocas pistas, pero la necesaria para ambientar, además que tiene muy buenos efectos de sonido.
[/list]

[h1]+Accesibilidad: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Múltiples idiomas, incluido el español, como ya lo mencioné, 100% recomendado en este idioma, por la gran cantidad de referencias y memes de nuestro idioma (ESTU*IDO Y SENSUAL FLANDERS).
[*]Es accesible con los streamers, tiene configuraciones para esta plataforma, modo speedrun si lo deseas.
[/list]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]+En síntesis: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Un juego increíble, me he divertido con el genial humor que maneja, sus mecánicas son muy básicas, pero el juego apunta mas a la comedia que a tomarse en serio, recomendable si quieres tener un momento divertido. Tiene varios memes de internet y tienen sentido en el juego, eso ya es un logro.
[/list]

84230575.review:
An adventure puzzle platformer. You go out into the world, collect items to progress and die throughout the game in order to make changes in the world and, hopefully, progress further next time. You need to watch what items you take as your jump becomes shorter with every item you pick up. It doesnt take itself too seriously and is meant to be funny and somewhat slapstick.

Problem is, it can get quite repetitive doing the same stuff over and over trying to find a new way to progress a bit more each time. Initially its fun and amusing, but when you start doing the same thing 15 times in a row in less than an hour wondering what havent I tried yet or what has changed, then you get kinda tired.

Im not a big fan of pixel graphics, nor do I want to grind the same stuff over and over for slightly different playthroughs. I acknowledge that this may be a fine product for its audience at a good price, but dont let the super high review score fool you, its not for everyone.

5/10

84225872.review:
This is yet another retro 2D pixel platformer/brawler bundlemeat shovelware infesting Steam.   This one has "different endings" but it's a bit hard to tell because of the awful graphics. 

They chose to use obsolete retro pixel "art" as a substitute for contemporary PC graphics.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget or talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low as a result.  The game seems to display in an obscure resolution when you go to full screen, but it doesn't make much difference because pixel "art" looks awful at any resolution.  It doesn't even look like games that were forced to use low resolution graphics in the past (because they had no alternative), it just looks ugly because they were lazy/unable to do better. 

Lazy development aside the gameplay is a bit clunky and just not very appealing or enjoyable.

83194361.review:
This game is actually real cool. But you have to be ready for a lot of backtracking and failed attempts. You will also need to memorize the (quite big) map roughly, but this will come naturally as you play.

Don’t worry, after some time you will unlock some shortcuts so your journeying can be easier. The shortcuts are unlocked after a certain ending is reached.

The game also has collectible hints lying on the ground and after reaching a set number of ending you will unlock a compass that points in the direction of the ending of a chosen hint. After getting yet more endings you will unlock a map that pinpoints the ending’s location.

I initially thought that the whole game was going through the endings using trial-and-error, which put me off and I stopped playing. But after I discovered that you get these aids the game feels a lot more directed, although there can still be some frustration.

If you’re looking for quick and easy fun this is perhaps not for you, but if you enjoy finding collectibles and logical puzzles then you will like this game.

83102661.review:
Do you remember the fun, nukeing megaton and change the fallout-world?
If the answer is "No, that was not fun" then this game may be nothing for your serious interests.
If its "wtf are you spoiling?!" then why tf are you reading this? Go and f-ing BUY Reventure instantly!
If its "Yes" then good news: in Reventure your actions change the gaming world.
If its "Yes, but it was a pain to cut off some quests" then even better news: The more you change the world the more you progress! 

And not only the world changes, but also your Character, depending on your actions. 
The games story itself is as shallow as it can be: "Rescue the princess from the bad guy".
To understand the greatness about the storytelling in Reventure you will see that the told story is not really about the quest, but about the hero and his actions. This is what keeps character development awesome and entertaining in this pixel world. 
Though I would like to play the game in real detailed graphics, I totally understand and enjoy the point of the decision to keep it pixel art. And the Devs did a really great job to play with it. 

At the beginning it may look a bit frustrating with "all that options". But really soon you will ejoy trying to do as many stupid things as possible. 
Then after you had some great laughes you will start the real "work" to get all the endings. This is the point were it gets a bit tricky. Especially if you found a way to conquer new places and then have to decide to go further or get a new ening and start all the way over. It's not THAT bad, since the world is not too big. But it can be a little bit frustrating from time to time. But nevertheless always funny and interesting. 

I dunno if there is a map in the guides. And I would give the advice not to use it if so. Because - like I mentioned earlier - the world is changing. And knowing about all the secrets will greatly take some fun away. Probably it would be good to have a finished map later in the game, when you are looking for the very last few endings. I did not play this far yet, so I don't know. But it definitely is a good thing to draw your own map for less frustration in wayfinding. 

Since the game IS awesome and the price IS low for what you get, I have to recommend it totally.

80949377.review:
I really like this game. It has a really cool idea, concept-wise. You travel the land and every time you die (in a dumb or hilarious way) you unlock something new for the next time you play. New shortcuts, items, NPC's and even features. The goal is the get all 100 different endings; which feels really rewarding. There are secrets everywhere and many different paths to take.
On top of that there is great workshop support for custom skins to put on your character. The game even has Twitch support which, from personal experience, works great and adds a fun way to interact with your chat.
If you truly want to get every single thing in the game (including the post-game content) there is one thing I must warn you for though. You could consider this a spoiler, so continue reading at your own discretion.
Ah-hum...

To get literally everything (and 100% achievements) you have to...

Kill a bunch of cats. And they make very sad noises when you do so. If you are a cat owner or an animal lover in general (like me) this is a major flaw. I know you can skip it and not get 100% achievements, but this game encourages exploration and getting all the other achievements. To make this one step required is unnecessary and cruel.

I give this game a 9/10. Would have been a perfect 10 if not for the cats.

Kudos for an original concept, charming pixel art, chirpy chiptune OST and clever storytelling, but there's really not enough to keep you busy. Maybe worth it on sale or in a bundle.

79726334.review: Reventure is a unique retro metroidvania game developed and published by Pixelatto in June of 2019. Unlike other metroidvania games which focus on slow forward progress, the goal of Reventure is instead to die over and over again. There are 100 different “endings” to the game, most of them involving humorous ways to get the hero killed. I have gotten about half of the endings so far, and have enjoyed the game thoroughly up to this point. The game does start to slow down somewhat as you progress, as the different endings start to get more and more obscure. It is very interesting how they chose to balance items in this game. You have a maximum amount you can carry at any one time, and the more you are carrying the less jump height you get. This prevents you from accessing other areas, and encourages the player to be efficient in carrying as few items as needed at any time. Reventure does quickly get repetitive, but it can be argued that is the entire point of the game. Overall I have thoroughly enjoyed playing Reventure thusfar and would recommend it to metroidvania fans with a sense of humor. Now if Pixelatto were to make a real metroidvania game with this same style, depth and sense of humor they could have a fantastic game on their hands.

77455634.review:
Reventure is a fun little platformer absolutely packed with content. It's pretty short but sweet!

[b]GAMEPLAY[/b]
The central gimmick of Reventure is that you get a different ending for doing almost everything. Kill a soldier, get an ending. Jump off a cliff, get an ending. You get the idea. Obviously every ending can be considered a spoiler, so I'll refrain from telling any more.

It's a very, very simple platformer with incredibly easy controls. All you have are two buttons and the arrow keys, that's all! I played it with a keyboard and it was perfectly fine since the platforming does not require the precision and fluidity of a controller. Except for a few tricky sections, you can generally breeze through the game.

The real challenge is the trial-and-error method by which you have to play to discover various endings. Technically the game has very high replay value, since to unlock the 100 (or is it 100 at all? :P) unique endings, you need to play it at least 100 times. What makes each Reventure run enjoyable is that you're not inclined to do the same thing each run, so every run is as unique as possible.

Unlocking various endings will also unlock some shortcuts, which will accelerate your quest to hunt MORE endings!

[b]STORY[/b]
It's a simple story about rescuing the Princess who has been kidnapped by a Dark Lord. Or is it? I cannot say too much because that would (at least partly) spoil the fun of discovering the entire story. NPC dialogs and the endings themselves are smartly written, with the occasional dose of dark humor. With a game like this you kind of expect it to break the fourth wall, and in that front Reventure does not disappoint.

[b]GRAPHICS[/b]
Initially I was a bit put off by the 'big pixel' style. Admittedly, this style works very well for the game. A visually dense, cluttered style would detract from the fast-paced gameplay, because once you get addicted to Reventure, you will perform many, many playthroughs in one go!

[b]MUSIC AND SOUND[/b]
The music is fine. By the time you 100% this game, you can hum almost all tunes in the game.

[b]OVERALL RATING: 8.5 OUT OF 10[/b]
Totally worth it if you like short, gimmicky platformers. I will certainly be looking out for the next game from Pixelatto!

Excellent game with some built-in weaknesses. 

Pro's:
+ It's as indie as it gets. Get this to play something entirely different from before
+ Endings 0-25 will give you good laughs

Con's
- At around endings 25-50 you realize the fooling around is about to end and now the real game begins. 
- At around 50+ it's obvious it's serious now. World is changing according to what your endings have been. New paths and items become available. You accidentally nuke stuff.  You reach the princess and.... weird stuff happens.  Luckily there are still laughs to be made but logistics is starting to be really something now as items need to moved long distances. 
- Endings 75+ it seems very few go this far. At 69% completed i see that only 14.6% people have got this far according the game stats. 

So basically here is an indie game that is as indie as it can possibly get that gives you lots of good laughs but will put your stamina to test as it progresses. Don't even think about unlocking 100 endings just like that. It is a big chore but in small sessions it is worth it. I like the 'what happens if i try this/go there' thinking that the game forces you to do. I also personally like the world design. The mountains the dark castle etc. Love it when you learn the layouts slowly. Also secret passages. lots and lots of secret passages. Weird amount of secret passages. And you better remember most of them.

76304923.review:
Note: I was given this game for free, but not from the developers themselves.

I am quite mixed on Reventure, as there were a lot of aspects I enjoyed but also a few major flaws in my opinion. After playing for 11 hours and getting all the endings/achievements, I feel confident in my decision to give it a negative review. This isn't to say it's a completely worthless experience, as I did rather enjoy my early hours of the game, but it got less engaging the longer I played, almost exponentially so. 

Reventure starts out almost like a puzzle game, where you end up trying every wacky action you can think of in order to seek out different endings. Eventually, you get to a point where you can predict many of the actions which will provide new endings, and there's a clever hint collectible system which helps speed along this process. However, once you achieve a good mental layout of the map and start having to grind very specific actions to get the remaining endings, the game really begins to drag, becoming tedious and even obnoxious at times. I'd say I noticed this changed around the 75% completion mark. It was at that point that I was no longer having fun and only continued just out of an obligation to finish, with my opinion of the game rapidly diminishing. It was just too long for the type of game it was, and many of the endings required the same repetitive series of actions over and over.

The game is interesting, but never actually challenging until you start the grind for that last bunch of endings, trying everything you can think of within reason, at which point it's no longer fun. From the very start, the actual gameplay is absurdly easy, being more focused on comedy and exploration more than anything else, but when the jokes start to lose their effectiveness and you run out of new paths to take, it becomes a chore: a dull 2D retro platformer where you walk through the same screens hundreds of times to attempt some arbitrary task on the other side of the map. Eventually I was just begging for it all to end so I could move on to a game that actually requires focus and/or skill.

So, in conclusion, I can't blame those that like this game, and I'd probably recommend it myself if it were less bloated, but I strongly advise against playing it if you feel the compulsive need to finish your games, as you'll probably end up gradually despising it like me. You can add all the clever jokes, pop-culture references, character skins, and continuity details you want in your game, but after all those lose their charm, you're just left with another boring fetch-quest walking simulator. I'm glad I got it for free, otherwise I'd certainly feel ripped off.

76207105.review:
Imagine a game where the objective is to find as many ways to mess up your adventure. Enter...Reventure! As it describes, this game is a very non-linear adventure game where the story isn't important, except to imagine the ways in how it could go wrong. I do love games that give me the kind of freedom to go about my way like this and this game did hit it for me. It also gave me a few amusing chuckles with some of the descriptions in how your fate was met.

Reventure has some charm in that it's humor is primarily tongue-in cheek and while not every joke is a hitter, there's a few things in it that's funny. Even though it's got all of that going for it, I can see where Reventure may not be for everyone. There's a lot of backtracking for you to do and the novelty can wear itself thin after prolonged play through. The cool thing about Reventure is that you can't always repeat all of your mistakes, thankfully, it's one time and you're done. With some exceptions, however. One of the only endings I'll give is that there's a stone you trip over and after that ending, you can just walk through it just fine.

All of the other endings, which there are 100 of them to get, you're on your own for that one. I only advise to think a little outside of the box and not take the adventure seriously to get an idea on how to achieve the feats. That is pretty much the requirement to enjoy this game and if you're not that kind of player, then you're honestly not going to find a thing to enjoy.

75618489.review:
I started playing this thinking it was a simple, low-budget game with a "collect all the endings" gimmick. To a large degree, that's exactly what Reventure is. However, I was pleasantly surprised when I found myself drawn in by the surprising depth and level of craft behind the gameplay. The initial overwhelming nature of being presented with a (relatively) large world to explore where seemingly every action leads to a humorous ending begins to give way to a more strategic game where you have to pay attention to which areas can be accessed with which items, how to circumvent restrictions that would normally keep you from having a certain item in a certain place, how to use unlockable short cuts to your advantage, etc. The constant-restart nature of the game lends itself very well to experimentation and exploration without failure ever seeming too punishing, and the constant stream of new skins you unlock add a bit of visual variety that keeps things interesting.

I had a lot of fun with Reventure. The hundredth ending was a great way to wrap up the experience, more so than the additional content that leads to the 101st ending. In fact, unless you're a real completionist I wouldn't recommend putting in the effort for that last achievement as doing so was one of the only frustrating parts of the game where tasks felt a little too drawn-out and punishing for their own good (when I unlocked a prototype version of the game with its own set of endings to unlock I started to feel like the concept was wearing out its welcome a bit).

But for the most part this was a pleasant surprise and an enjoyable experience with more than a few laughs. Recommended.

74149809.review:
After 150 years...I found it.

Reventure doesn't seem very deep at first. It's a cute 8-bit style with unlockable skins familiar to adventure gamers and obtainable items that affect where you can go/do (bombs, hookshot, shield, etc). Yet as you play you slowly discover a much more intricate world at hand for you to explore the secrets of.

The short of it is that Reventure plays like a choose-your-own-adventure style roguelike where there are literally over 100 endings depending on what you do (from killing yourself to saving the princess to really digging deep and killing all the developers). I played through each ending and they are all pretty funny. As you complete certain endings you unlock permanent changes to the world such as teleporters or just a guard dog.

If you read those kind of books and don't mind a little repetition getting to know this world, I think this is a great game for you!

73931452.review:
I think the trailer is somewhat misleading. It conveys to me that the game is some form of rogue-like. It's not. It's a Fail-simulator, like Kindergarten, or the Henry Stickman browser games. The goal isn't to die and retry until you find the right way to get to the end, its to discover all the wonderful ways you can fuck up royaly for shits and giggles, doing all the ridiculous things you originally try your best to avoid while playing a video game, 

Now that that's cleared up, this game is hilarious. The writing and comical execution of the.....executions, is laugh out loud funny. Gameplay isn't difficult or deep, but does require some exploration and out of the box thinking to get all of the endings, Some of which are admittedly tedious to get due to repetition and time. None are particularly difficult to figure out (Except ending #95 for me because I was overthinking it). 

The only particular stain on this game is the tower of Screw You (my name for it). It too isn't insanely hard, but more so arduous to complete, being one of those "you fail at any point, and you have to start all over" type challenges where the challenges are deliberately made so that they can be easy to mess up. Thankfully it short, and again, not too hard, and at least the reward is somewhat worth while compared to other games that pull this BS.

Overall this is a fantastically funny puzzler solver Fail-simulator with great exploration and writing, lots of secrets to find, and an endearingly pleasant art and soundtrack. I got this as a part of a bundle on Fanatical for 4$ that I wasn't even getting for this game, and was surprised at how much I enjoyed it as I didn't realize I was getting such a great game. By itself, I'd drop a Lincoln (5$ ) on it, so getting this on sale is a deal.

73703509.review:
[h2]I didn't know it was going to be this fun![/h2]
So far, I'm about 60% complete. And I'm going to keep coming back each day to get all the endings. This is such a well thought out design! In a nutshell, you have to find all the endings, to do this, you have to think outside the conventional box that is common to mainstream games. It's this breaking of the convention that makes me giggle. 

There's a lot to say for such a simple, yet so ultimately impactful title. You will learn the world on a very personal level and begin to learn the mechanics and rules of the world all while learning about all the endings. It's cleverly worked out. One example of this is [spoiler]the weight mechanic.[/spoiler] The developers know that you're going to be greedy, so they know that 99% of players will find this ending very quickly. Once the player does it teaches them through failure (IMO the best way to learn anything).

That brings me to something so unique to this title. Failure is success. If you die, that's a good thing, as you've likely unlocked a new ending, which means you're closer to completion. Mind-blowing stuff, but again, the system is so simple, and I adore this!

Buy it now! And begin failing to succeed!


Seriously! If you want a laugh and a few hundred giggles, this is the game for you. I think there's a certain level of crazy required to think of all the endings and complete them without a tutorial.

73656874.review:
[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Reventure is an adventure game about death. You are tasked with discovering all the different possible endings to your story.

Along the way, you discover items that can help you overcome certain obstacles, like a shovel to help you dig, a sword to help you fight, etc. The gameplay is mostly platforming oriented with very little combat. Outside of the first 10-15 deaths, each ending is similar to a puzzle, where you need to discover all the ingredients for this specific scenario. While this can begin to get frustrating, the game avoids this by randomly spawning hint scrolls for you to find. They give a short hint about 1 undiscovered ending. It ensures that each hint is useful and progresses the game, without completely spoiling the fun of discovery. There are some items you can find that give you new ways to explore levels, giving some variety to the platforming.

Everything in Reventure is centered around finding new ways to die. Visually, this manifests in the form of certain deaths unlocking costumes that thematically fit with the outcome. The art is fairly simplistic pixel art, but the gameplay tends to distract from the graphics, so it doesn’t really hurt the overall game.

The sound design isn’t anything special, but it does its job. The sound effects and soundtrack are decent, but fail to stand out as good work.

The game’s writing is often funny and interesting, even if it falls flat a couple times. The plot is essentially one giant, branching storyline, and surprisingly, it all fits together pretty well.

Repetitiveness is Reventure’s biggest strength and weakness. At its best, the game has you exploring new, yet related, ways to end the game. It’s fun to see all the different possibilities. Yet the big problem is that doing for this for too long makes it boring after a while. This game is best played in short bursts over a long period of time. You always start the game the same way, so you never need to get caught up with what you forgot.

Overall, Reventure uses its unique idea perfectly, creating a great adventure loop. The presentation isn’t the best, but the gameplay makes up for it easily. Strongly recommended to adventure game fans who are looking for a fresh take on the genre.

8/10

73568208.review: I think this falls under the sort of category of game that if you look at the store page you can sort of tell if you'd like it or not. Easy puzzle game in the form of an indie platformer. It's not super challenging since there's barely any combat, and so what that translates to is the game largely being about rewarding exploration and finding solutions to mild routing puzzles. Every time you start the game you start with nothing, and if you get an ending you restart from that static beginning. Different items allow the player character to reach different areas and different endings, but most items have a weight that reduce jump height, meaning there's a tradeoff and you get to have fun figuring out what combination of things can let you achieve the ending you want. Good graphics, mostly good humor, good music, and as you run up the ending list an appreciable but still pretty gentle difficulty curve that won't leave an interested player bored. My only real complaint about the game is when you're a bit deeper into it is that it paradoxically feels repetitive when you have to run and get the same items but for a different ending. You can't save before an ending, get it, reload, and go for a different ending either, which is a minorly disagreeable design choice.

73270121.review:
I finally decided to check this out after having seen it around for a year or so, and having followed the dev on Twitter, who is pretty funny on there as well. here are my thoughts after about 3 hours of playtime and 31 endings found:

+ nice pixel art and music, it's easy on the eyes and ears.
+ solid platforming with tight controls, but what really sells its gameplay is more the logic required to suss out all of the different endings. "okay, I need to get the sword and the bomb to get into this area and then jump onto this to probably set off a different ending." it's a game that I don't recommend using a walkthrough for, cuz you'll eventually figure things out just by running your head up against a wall a bunch. a few non-spoilery tips though: if you find a secret area, that reveals any other secret areas on your screen. you can chop bushes with your sword, so if you get too heavy to be able to jump over a bush, just cut it a bit. sometimes you'll even find secret areas behind bushes after cutting them down.
+ what I think is its greatest strength, though, is its fantastic sense of humor and writing. the gameplay actually plays nicely into the jokes, which is great to see.
+ the persistence of the story adds to the jokes. after each ending you discover, the story continues. which makes things more and more ludicrous throughout. you get to forge your own dynamic tale of wannabe heroes falling over themselves to fail in their quests of saving the princess, in ways that are even more amusing when you step back and consider how every ending before you has been canon.
+ there's a fun, pseudo-competitive aspect to things where after each ending, you see how many others have found as many endings as you. one of my first priorities when I saw that was to get myself into the top 50% (I am, and now very close to being in the top 40%*). this adds to the fun of things, and is pretty unique.
*took me about 25 more minutes to break into the top 40%. after about 8 hours and over 60 endings found, I'm now in the top 17% or so. (which should give you an idea of how many people have sought to beat the game in full, or tried to.)
+ there are no real "failure states" in this, which I don't think is inherently a good or bad thing. you could say that the failure state is getting the same ending over again, cuz that's a waste of time, but even when you "die," you've made progress by finding a new ending. at the end of the day, I think that this is what's right for this specific game--it's more of a laid back, chill affair where you drop in and mess around with various item combinations.

overall, I think this game is one of a kind, and very enjoyable. will definitely be attempting to find all of the endings over time. it's fun to jump in, find five or six, and then see you jump into a whole 'nother percentile of players.

72530499.review:
If you're the type of person who enjoys inventory-based puzzle platformers like the old Dizzy games, you will love Reventure.  If you're not familiar with the style, you have a very limited inventory that you can fill with items from the game world, and each item has various uses at different spots in the world.  The puzzle is in figuring out what combination of items and interactions you need to unlock more progress.  

The in-game hint system is very good if you get stuck, and the game's twist on the whole setup is hilarious.  The difficulty and time spent retreading over old ground does increase as you go on, but across the entire game, I would say only one or two things were actually tedious instead of fun  With 100 endings, that's a pretty good ratio.
